description:
Of all the restaurants in the neighborhood, this is definitely my go-to for a casual, tasty, and affordable meal. I've dabbled across the menu and been pleased by everything so far. Vermicelli with the Imperial rolls is one of my favorite dishes as the crunchy roll contrasts with the soft noodles and pork. 

The portions are a decent size (enough for leftovers for me) with a nice pile of bean sprouts and basil for pho dishes. Service is also prompt and friendly, great for take-out. It really has a home cooked feel with an older Vietnamese woman sitting in the corner filling and folding dumplings as proof.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Imperial spring rolls should always look like this. 

5 star for imperial rolls. Also the Asian grandpa is really nice
author: Linda L.

description:
I remember coming here with my boyfriend around 2:30PM on a Tuesday. There weren't many other customers but lots of staff available, yet it was a struggle to get their attention and help. Even asking for some water without ice took 20 minutes - we would see our waiter idly sitting at a far away table not helping out anyone. My boyfriend had to stand up, walk across the restaurant, and remind him to get us some water because he had forgotten about it. 

We ended up splitting an order of beef pho between the two of us. When we tried it, I noticed it was very salty and mostly broth. In fact, the only flavor I could detect from the pho was salt - and a lot of it. There was hardly any meat and a subpar amount of noodles. 

Needless to say, I was disappointed in our food and experience. I'm surprised this place has such high ratings despite our terrible experience here. If this is the standard of this establishment, then I would not recommend Kim Son Vietnamese Restaurant to anyone.
author: Liselle L.

description: Love this place! I used to come with my family every once in a while. I'm not a huge fan of pho but I would crave it occasionally. This place is very affordable and is rather quick. When I come here I appreciate that they have other options other than pho and I like their portion sizes. Especially when I was younger, they had smaller sizes which was perfect for me
author: Shaeli Z.

description:
One of the best pho I've had in a really long time... Arguably the best in the city. 

Their most popular phos are #23 - the spicy beef and pork pho and #24 - crab paste and tomato noodle soup (psttt it also has pork in it but you can ask to have it removed if you're a pescatarian).

We also got their Make you own rice vermicelli for an appetizer. This was so good but you definitely need a group of at least four people. 

Give it a shot, they're worth the trip.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Pho is not usually my dish of choice, but I was after some lighter fare. Found this place on Yelp, and the pictures of their vegan pho immediately had my mouth watering.  

It did not disappoint. I actually ordered mine without the noodles, extra veggies instead, and they sure did deliver! Tons of shitakes and bok choi and broccoli, and the tofu is fried to firmness, not that soft boring stuff they usually add. Fresh toppings were your typical basil, bean sprouts, jalapenos, and lime. Each table is stocked with chop sticks and chili sauces, too, which is convenient. I dislike having to request them. 

Portions are so generous, I left stuffed, and still packed some to go. Prices are very fair. My only gripe, and the reason I knocked off a star was the fact that, after bringing our soup, our server forgot about us. No water refills and it took forever to get the check. 

I'd still go back, though...
author: Ellery D.

description:
This is one of 3 Vietnamese restaurants that I like in SF. The other two are on Irving.

Highlights: 
-best bun rieu! I came with my friend who is also a Yelp queen and picky pho taster, and she loved it.
-love that we could order half spring roll and half imperial roll (fried). At other restaurants, it's one or the other
-located next to Purple Kow, for some boba drinks

And for these reasons, I will keep coming back.
author: Corinna T.

description:
I just ordered take out and I must say the service here was much better than your typical Vietnamese restaurant. They care a lot about their customers and I got checked on 5x while I was waiting on my to-go order. 

I did wish we ate in because the portion sizes looked huge. One bowl looked big enough for my boyfriend and I. In our to-go order, we got Bun rieu and Bun Bo Hue. Bun bo hue was good. My boyfriend is vietnamese and he's actually from Hue so he knows what's up. So his biggest complaint is when bun bo hue is not served with the banana leaves. But that didn't bother him because he still finished it.

The Bun Rieu was for me and I love bun rieu. Flavor of broth was awesome and felt very homey, but the items in the bun rieu were not my favorite. It had an entire egg in there and didn't have the crab paste thing. Why?! That's what it's known for! However, the pork and shrimp and the stuff actually inside was delicious. The crab paste thing is what makes bun rieu, bun rieu. However, I know with these home dishes, every place has their own unique spin and recipe to it. 

Because of this I took off one star; however I loved the people, the service, portion sizes, and the food! It was still delicious and you can't go wrong with the things we ordered. 

Best in town? I can see that for the bun rieu for some, but not the bun bo hue.. but Is it a good place to get these delicious offerings? YES. Definite Recommend and would come back.
author: Josie W.

description:
The pho really hit the spot here. After a night of drinking the day prior, I woke up needing pho. Luckily, we found metered parking right away and was seated. It's a pretty big space, so not crowded at all. They are also able to accomodate large parties as I saw a party of 15 come in later on. 

I ordered #3 Pho Tai (Fresh Sliced Beef Noodle Soup) ($8.95), which came out within 5-10 minutes. I was so happy with how quick it came out. The pho itself was a huge bowl too. It came with plenty of noodles and meat in a flavorful broth. This is the perfect hangover remedy and this spot does it very well.
author: Cindy Z.

description: Came here for breakfast while visiting SF.  Needed something warm.  Order their pho. It was pretty good. Also order their coffee.  Place was clean and service was great.  Service was quick and we got our food fast.  I will most definitely come back.
author: Mary T.

description: This place is a ways out of the way if you don't live on the west side, but I'm always willing to traverse across San Francisco for their consistently good Vietnamese food.  When I'm craving a familiar, homecooked meal, I hit up this place. Their canh chua ca and ca kho to are what I'm used to--robust flavors and they only use catfish.  Their eggrolls are great too--big portions served with lettuce, bun, and pickled veggies.  I've only eaten here to-go, but every time I pick up my food, the restaurant is packed, which only confirms how good it is!
author: Crystal C.

description:
Nice spacious family-owned business in Outer Richmond right next to Balboa theater! Great prices, fairly clean, delicious food. Everything I want in a Vietnamese joint. 

I ordered the vermicelli plate with imperial roll and grilled pork. It was very satisfying, filling, and also only $13 (tax + tip included!). Loved the crunch on the imperial roll. Everything I was looking for after catching a movie right next door. 

Service is very fast. There are big tables around if you'd like to bring a group.
author: Cindy W.

description: This Vietnamese restaurant is like any other restaurant with the usual pho, vermicelli plate, and rice plate; however, I do have to say, the broth is more flavorful. My husband got the 5 spice chicken with rice plate and he thoroughly enjoyed it. He asked for eggroll added to his plate but got a cooked egg instead, but overall, he liked the added mistake so I won't complain.
author: Chong C.

description:
Great food and service
Authentic vietnamese cuisine good portion too
The server even friendly warned us to not over order
Try their spicy pho(BunBoHui) if you want something to spice you up! ;)
author: Isabelle Z.

description: For nearly the whole week, I had been craving Bun Rieu. Weird, I know. I'm not even that into Viet food but I had seen this IG vid on how it was cooked and suddenly, I couldn't get it out of my head. Good thing R loves viet food, especially Pho. We got here around 8-ish PM, which is the sweet spot because that's when people start leaving and we got seated almost instantly. R got the beef pho (#5?) extra large and I got the Bun Rieu. We also got an order of the imperial rolls. The imperial rolls were super filling and we felt like we were already a quarter full! The noodles came out pretty quick. R's extra large was so big. But we later discovered that the amount of noodles in there is not too bad, just that there was a lot of broth. The bun rieu was awesome. One thing though-there literally is only 3 shrimps in here. I know because I counted and they tasted kind of tough. Despite that, it was still pretty good. It's cheap, delicious, quick and best of all, they take card!
author: Michelle R.

description: The reviews recommended the Bun Rieu, so I went for it and it was an excellent choice! They serve a generous portion of rich and tangy crab, pork, and tomato broth, with lots of crab meat, noodles, shrimp and veggies. Thoroughly enjoyed my first time trying this pho!
author: Camille E.

description:
I've been to this restaurant before and have gotten take out from here numerous times. It's always been good, simple Vietnamese food. 

My roommate and I came last night and it wasn't too busy. After we sat down, it took about 10-15 minutes for us to be approached by staff. The food was ok, not as good as it normally is. My roommate got chicken noddle pho and I got the bbq chicken and pork combination plate. 

Apart from the mediocre food and service we received last night, what prompted me to post this review was the baskets of spring rolls that sat out at room temperature for the entire time we were in the restaurant. I've attached a photo - if they're serving those spring rolls in the red baskets to customers, that's absolutely disgusting and can't be up to code. 

I'm all for hole in the wall spots, some of my favorite restaurants look a bit questionable- but this kind of pushed me over the edge.
author: Hannah W.

description: This is definitely in my top 5 of restaurants in the city. No frills, no fuss but what this restaurant lacks in razzle dazzle makes up for it with its fresh, light and flavorful food. I swear by the rice plates (the five spice chicken is BOMB!) and the vermicelli bowls! I've never been disappointed at Son Kim and I will also have an affinity for this establishment in the quiet Outer Richmond!
author: Danielle D.

description: No wait line just walked right in. Friendly service and excellent food. I ordered the veggie pho with veggie broth and it did not taste bland. I'd definitely come back to this joint. Bookmarked!
author: Lucia R.

description:
I came here with my family on a weekday afternoon around 1pm, the staff was a bit slow but I think thats because they were on lunch break. 

I ordered a regular size pho, but i should have ordered a large. The small did not fill me up at all. The com tam dishes here looked so delicious,  and definitely had alot more food compared to the pho.  Prices are reasonable,  the pho was tasty and not too salty. 

Next time I come, I will order the com tam!
author: Tiffany Y.

description: I've come here many times for the vegetarian pho. It's consistently flavorful and packed with veggies and tofu. The portions are big and generous here, I don't think I've ever managed to finish a whole bowl haha. Also, I am always happy with the vegetarian spring rolls, paired with a peanut sauce. They never go wrong.
author: Hannah M.

description:
Honestly the best pho broth I've ever had, and to grab it in a rainy day was perfect. I've had hundreds of pho and personally the broth is the hardest flavor to master. The serving size is big for the price you pay ($6.95 for pho- no meat and $8.95 for pho w/ tendon) and We had leftovers. 

Service was good, we asked for a handful of extra things and they gladly gave. My mom's a fan of lemon so when they brought her a bowl-full, she was pretty happy! They don't hover but are attentive and know when to come by. 

Overall the clean and delicious! 10/10 would come again in a heartbeat
author: Angella G.

description:
Pretty decent Vietnamese place and cheap in SF.
I ordered Bun Rieu, Thai tea, empire rolls.
People on yelp said Bun Riue here is really good so I gotta try. It was good. Much more crabby taste than other places. Ones i usually try is more tomato taste but this one was clear and crabby flavor. I liked the soup. But I am not Bun rieu person and wasnt super amazed. I want to try something else and re write a review.
Empire rolls were great too.
author: Nazuki Y.

description: Wonderful pho at a very reasonable price. Nothing fancy, but the food comes quickly and tea is included.
author: Brandon H.

description:
The portions are very big, we could have split our orders easily.
My husband had #38 Bun Bo Xao, with cooked bean sprouts and vermicelli. Sautéed with lemon grass. Good and tasty.

I noticed all the pics of #24 Bun Rieu on Yelp so that's what i ordered. I was not disappointed. Again we could have ordered one bowl of the Bun Rieu or Vermicelli and split it, that's how big the portions were.

I also ordered the egg rolls, decent. At least they didn't make it with taro root which i dislike with a passion. Adding taro root to a egg rolls l is like adding baby's breathe to floral arrangement. Filler.

I will be going back to try other items.  i know it's going to be good when it's cooked, run and the customers are all Vietnamese.

It's not like fantastic Vietnamese but it's good and priced accordingly.
author: Judi L.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here on a late Friday morning (after a medical appointment.) There is plenty of parking around the restaurant. Also, no wait at all, though the restaurant was mostly empty. 

I ordered a combination pho, and my boyfriend ordered one of the vermicelli bowls. It was definitely good - the best Vietnamese food I've had in this area of SF so far! I thought it was a good portion of food and ratio of noodles to meat. Will come back again to try out their other dishes.
author: Christine L.

description:
For some of the best pho in town, you come to Kim Son. Any sort of warm noodle soup craving will bring me out to this spot, regardless of how crappy the parking situation may get. FYI, parking anywhere in the Richmond sucks. Especially where these busier streets are, filled with restaurants. It also doesn't help that the infamous Purple Kow is right next door. Get your boba. Get your pho!! 

Not gonna lie, I don't actually get pho here, even though that's what I've been raving about this the whole time. I actually come for the bun rieu. Finding a great Vietnamese restaurant who makes bun rieu like how it's supposed to be made (without meat) is so rare. Or can actually accommodate to my dietary needs...aka minus the pork. But Kim Son has always done it right! The rest of the fam def gets the pho, vermicelli bowls, and build your own spring roll apps. 

SOO good. SOO legit. 5 stars!!

PS during my last visit, I saw the waiter leave with veggies in hand (in a box), walk across the street to Mr Banh Mi. Do they own this new restaurant too?! Probably. Checked it out after I finished my meal, and glad to see a banh mi shop open up at the end of the avenues. Downside is that they've taken all the fish items off their menu already! Sadness
author: Jennifer L.

description: My coworkers and I order take out here at least once a week. The food is yummy with large portions at a great price. I always end up full and satisfied. Some of our favorites are BBQ chicken pho, pork combo rice plate, bun rieu, bun bo hue, shrimp spring rolls, imperial rolls, salty plum soda, thai iced tea. Service is quick and efficient when I call it in and it's usually ready in 20 mins for pick up. Great food at a great price, can't ask for more!
author: Annie L.

description: Everything here is pretty good and pretty authentic for Vietnamese restaurant in the Outer Richmond.
author: Dao C.

description:
I first visited this restaurant when I was a vegan in 2016. I was attracted by the vegetarian pho but I ended up getting spring rolls instead. 

Now that I've had the pho I enjoy it, but I recommend their vegetarian soup more. 
I recommend also getting the Thai tea because it's really sweet :)
author: Cynthia M.

description:
A simple, homey type of place with feel-good food. Would come back again for cheap eats next time I'm in the area. Pros: price, flavors, number of veg options, portion-size; Cons: dishes can be hit or miss, simple atmosphere

Food: Lots of veg options here!! The vegetarian fried rice was incredible. Lots of fresh vegetables and good flavor -- definitely a little on the heavier side. Their vegetarian pho wasn't my favorite -- they didn't find a good way to make the broth flavorful enough. Non-veg broths will probably prove tastier. All other dishes around the table were well-received. 

Atmosphere: Very casual spot with Lazy Susan tables for family-style eating (I love those). Nothing fancy or "hip", but gets the job done. 

Value: I probably wouldn't have offered anything higher than 3.5 stars if it weren't for the price. Most entrees are $7-12 with healthy portions -- can't beat it. 

Service: Our waitress was incredibly kind and checked back regularly during the meal.
author: Deena M.

description: The place was a full house and I can imagine it'd be like that often because it's THAT good. The food was flavorful and fast. The pho and udon was quality. The service was good and you could tell they have good roots invested into this place. We even ordered some fried rice to go which was as delicious.
author: Natalie E.

description: I came here to try out the much acclaimed crab paste noodle soup..it was okay...too busy. too much noodles, it's certainly cheap i give you that and it's a good lunch option on a cold day but nothing to write home about...
author: Xiu L.

description:
I come here at least once a month for my hangover cures.

LOVE: the vegetarian broth, rice and egg noodles, seafood pho, imperial rolls, quality of foood, healing powers for a hangover

EEEH: that it's so far from my house in the city. But I'd rather drive 20 minutes for this pho than just a mediocre one close to my house
author: Jul C.

description:
Soooooo gooooddd. Super inexpensive, food quality is amazing! Service and great MMMM 

They do take card now.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Leaving 5 stars because even though I didn't get my order the way I wanted it, the food was good and the server tried to be accommodating. I was told it was a 潮州 owned restaurant so I wanted to give it a shot. The wait staff doesn't speak 潮州 but I was able to order in Vietnamese.

I ordered off the menu asking for a h tiu bò viên. The waiter said they could accommodate that. Though both ph and h tiu are served with rice noodles (different broth) h tiu is traditionally served with flat rice noodles while ph is served with the thinner rice noodle, my dish came with the latter which made me a little disappointed. I was told in the future, at this establishment, to request the flat noodles.

Beyond that, the food tasted fresh and flavorful!
author: Orlando D.

description: This is place is great and the staff are super friendly. Usually pretty easy to get a table. I really like the #20 veggies soup with beef broth.
author: Dylan B.

description:
This is just for the Bun Rieu. I feel like Kim Son is one of the few places where the Bun Rieu has a strong seafood flavor. It's also not too tomato-y so the seafood flavor doesn't get overshadowed. I know this may sound blasphemous, but I like getting the pho noodles instead of the thin vermicelli. Just my personal preference, but I enjoy the texture of the pho rice noodles more. In any case, the Bun Rieu is good, and you should get it. 

I haven't had the chance to try much else, but I've heard good things about the broken rice plates. Probably not as good as the Bun Rieu though so just get that.
author: Nei N.

description:
super nice staff, great food, fair prices.
Owner is a great guy and wears nice men's shoes.
author: Adam G.

description:
I came in on a quiet Tuesday afternoon with hopes of having a stomach filled with a warm bowl of pho. I left, untouched and deep with the thoughts of, "Never again" and the questioning of how people were able to dine here.

-The server is very, very attentive. Right after we opened the menu, she appeared asking if we were ready to order. It was my first time, so I had to spend time flipping through the menu looking for specific words or pictures that would catch my eye. A few moments later, I glanced through Yelp pictures as a guidance to what would be an ideal meal for me. "Are you ready to order?" was asked again as I debated between a rice plate or simply just pho. "Not yet, give us five more minutes." I showed my mom pictures of the egg rolls and wide array of rice plates. "Are you ready to order?" as my mom and I ad libbed a list of orders.

-The pho they use seems thinner than the usual pho served at other restaurants. The broth was tasteless, but was at an unusually hot temperature when I lifted it to my place mat. They don't give that many ingredients in their pho, but the tendons really stood out to me. Unlike other pho restaurants, their tendons are soft and chewy-easy to swallow and digest.

-The com tam with pork chop and egg was something different. Even with it's familarity, I found the pork chops and egg to be dry tasting. I don't even think there was any fat in the pork chop to make it moist. 

Service is absent because there were times when I'd catch customers trying to give silence signals or catch the server's attention, while she'd aimlessly clean tables. The server here was quick to take orders, but the attitude she emitted was more of, "Eat then leave."
author: Erica K.

description: Man these Asian MuthaFukas know how to cook up some chicken pork soup all day. Bin hun was on point. Only issue was no fried bananas which is best banana desert n town besides the one you give or get every Friday night
author: The Jewbador H.

description:
Real talk I almost don't want to review this place because it's my spot and getting a seat on weekends is hard enough, but the thought of you eating mediocre Vietnamese makes me sad. 

Yeah the pho is obviously good but try the other stuff--the seafood crispy noodles are garlicky and better than at a lot of HK spots, the bbq pork and chicken are incredibly on point. The salty lemonade is refreshing after a sunny day in the park or at the beach. The crab and tomato soup is lovely if that's your thing and now that I think about it I've never ordered anything that wasn't. 

I love that the joint is owned by bossman and his fam, they give a damn and you can taste it too. Enjoy.
author: Jeremy Y.

description: After living in Seattle for a bit, I've gotten pretty spoiled with unique authentic vietnamese food.  SF has disappointed again. Don't get me wrong, the food isn't terrible here but it's not anything to scream to the moon about. A few pros are decent prices and big portions. For 2 people, we easily shared stir fried beef and imperial rolls with vermicelli. The Vietnamese offerings are about the same for what you would find in New York. Maybe San Jose has more interesting Vietnamese dishes..
author: Virginia Y.

description:
Tasty Vietnamese!
We ordered the sweet and sour fish, but kept the sauce on the side - I recommend doing this - Very good fish and nicely fried.

Also got - Vegetarian Imperial Roll, delicious! super crispy, full of glass noodles, mushrooms, eggs, carrots and much more with a great dipping sauce.

Five Spice Chicken was lovely, a huge amount of meat!  Great flavor.  I would have like the chicken to be a little crispy on the edges, but otherwise it was great.

Met the owner or manager, very sweet guy.
author: Song H.

description:
A really convenient option if you're catching a movie at the Balboa Theatre.  Had an interesting menu, but I tried their pho since it was my first time there and I absolutely love pho.  It was just ok though.  Perhaps I should have tried one of their platters instead.

Pho Bo w/ Beef Ball, Fresh Sliced Beef, Cooked Meat: Got by benchmark pho with all the meat available except tendon & tripe.  The broth was nice.  The noodles were standard.  I wasn't feeling the fresh sliced beef (i.e. eye round) since it wasn't that thinly sliced.  Problem is that when it's thick, it tastes like overcooked pot roast.  The beef balls were decent.  The brisket was ok, but they loaded up on the fatty slices instead of offering a diversity of cuts.
author: Adam B.

description:
Big portion and nice food! Not 100% perfect but very close to what you can get in Vietnam.
Southern cooking style, by the way!
author: Darren L.

description:
When we were in need of comfort food that warms you up from the inside out, Mr. Joy brought me to Kim Son. He said the pho here is better than the pho at Kevin's, to which I replied - pho at Kevin's is alright, not great. Golden Mountain looked like any other neighborhood Asian family-style restaurant. It is quite spacious and has the usual extensive menu with 100+ dishes. 
I chose the beef pho and Mr. Joy was right. It is pretty good. The beef broth was light, but had good flavor. More importantly, the tendons were soft and chewy, but not hard. The beef slices did not taste frozen. The pho comes in one size and it was a pretty large bowl. 
I approve. If I were in the area, I would definitely return to try their other affordable Vietnamese dishes.
author: Joy W.

description: No lie, I actually teared up when I had my first bite. I ordered the bun rieu and was immediately transported back in time to my Mom's bun rieu. This place is incredibly authentic, clean, and family-friendly. The food is incredible and I'll be sure to come here again.
author: Annhien N.

description: Great tasting Vietnamese food at a reasonable price. Fast and courteous service, unless they have a full house. Street parking only, so it might problematic on certain days.
author: Roland F.

description: Well I've been here at least 30 times, I order the #10  (chicken Pho) every time and it's amazing every time. The family that owns this business is so sweet. I've had pho all over SF and this place is hands down THE BEST.
author: Sarah S.

description: My favorite place in city for Bun Rieu. They have good options for appetizer and price and good portion of food. If you are near the area and love authentic Vietnamese food. This will be your place.
author: Happy R.

description:
Shared Bun Rieu and Spring Rolls with my wife on the way to Legion of Honor. 
Spring Rolls are very good. Bun Rieu is amazing!
The service was fast and efficient.   
Next time I want to try more dishes, on the other hand it would be a challenge to not order Bun Rieu again.
author: Ilya K.

description:
Let me start by saying they have the BEST bun rieu I've tried in a restaurant thus far. For $8.95 you get a generously sized bowl of hearty and flavorful tomato based broth filled with crab paste, tofu, shrimp, eggs, lettuce, mint leaves, and vermicelli noodles. Ughhh it was so perfect and hit all the right spots on a freezing winter night in San Francisco. 

My friend ordered #6 - pho with sliced beef and tendon. I tried some, and it was equally as delicious! The broth was flavorful and not overly loaded in MSG.

She finished her bowl of pho first and watched as I slowly ingested each piping hot bite of my flavorgasmic bun rieu. I kept reminding her how much in heaven I was. While working on devouring my bowl in its entirety, the waiter comes up with the check and two fortune cookies. He asks if we are finished eating, to which I reply that I'm not done yet. Next, I see him pick up my plate of chili dipping sauce ("hmm, what's he doing," I think to myself) and then.....*clank* the plate drops into my unfinished bowl of bun rieu. =000000000 connect those 0's and that's how my face probably looked.  Jaw. Dropped. Heart split into a million pieces. 

"I...I said I wasn't done yet," I gasped. 

His face had the literal expression of OH SH*T WHAT DID I JUST DO. "I thought you said you were done..." he replied.

"Oh, no... I said I was NOT done yet..."

He looked at my bowl and I could see him thinking "oh god what do I do. She didn't even have that much left, but I f'ed up :(" He apologized and responded saying he would go ask the kitchen to make me another small bowl.

I felt so bad! I told him that it was alright and that I didn't need the extra bowl. He rushed to the kitchen.

He then comes back with another fortune cookie and says that they are working on making me another bowl right away. By then, I was already set on not getting another bowl and asked if I could just get a discount on the check. Instead of giving me a discount, he takes the entire bun rieu off the bill! 

I was just in shock from the whole sequence of events. My dining experience went from pure bliss, to sudden heartbreak, to sympathizing, to utter disbelief and gratitude. 5 stars for the service and the food! Miscommunications happen. I totally understand. I'm 100% coming back to finish 100% of my next bowl of bun rieu there. ;)
author: Cheryl N.

description: I usually go here all the time it's pretty good. But tonight it was terrible horrifying actually. I wasn't feeling so well so I came to have some phó and while I was eating I saw BABY COCKROACH floating in my soup. I am mediately felt even worse!  I should've taken a photo but I felt so disgusted I am mediately walked outside to get some air.
author: Mary Grace B.

description:
The food is pretty meh. I come here mostly because it's the closet pho shop in the neighborhood. On the other hand, they have quite a lot of seats so I haven't had to wait ever.

If you are driving, go somewhere else. There are much better phos out there.
author: Joseph L.

description: pho for the God's. best pho i have ever had went here on 420. 5 spice bbq chicken pho soup with some springs rolls left satisfied and happy. The portions are huge couldnt even finish it
author: Carlos Z.

description:
When I first entered, staff were friendly. My friend and I made our way to a table and ordered 2 bowls of pho. Sadly one of the staffers forgot to write down our order.. and we didn't get our food.

I saw all the other tables who sat down after us get their food. The other staff didn't approach us at all, even though we were sitting there for a good 30 minutes with just cups of water. Eventually we flagged down an employee and had to re-order our food. 

Sadly there was no apology for the delay. It was just "oh", and then getting us our order. I admit the pho was decent. But after this service experience, I don't think I'll be back.
author: Ada P.

description: Feel very disappointed and dissatisfied. I ordered the bun bo hue and all the noodles were broken and short. The broth lacked a lot of spice and authenticity. Tasted flat. And there wasn't pork knuckle in it or pork blood. Felt like its catered to Caucasians and not Vietnamese people.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Recommend their Bún tht nng!!! Delicious AND healthy! Great for anyone hoping to lose 10lb for their NY resolution! 

FOOD: I got the Bún tht nng (#32), which according to Wikipedia, is a "cold rice vermicelli noodle dish...with grilled pork, herbs...salad and bean sprouts, and ch giò." It came with fish sauce on the side and my friend told me to add only 3/4 of it into the bowl, and leave the rest to dip the ch giò that came with the dish, which is ground pork wrapped in rice paper and deep fried. Everything tasted great in combination, and I really liked the ch giò. Definitely recommend this dish if you want something light and don't like wasting food (like with Pho you feel like you have to drink the soup to not waste it. Not a problem with this dish)!!! 

SERVICE: We were here Sunday during lunchtime and were seated immediately. Our food was ready in 10 minutes and the waiters are nice and attentive to our needs. 

SETTING: The restaurant is really spacious and seat maybe 50-60 people. There is a Purple Cow conveniently located right next door. Street parking is also do-able. 

PRICE: For $12 (+ tip,tax), I was really happy with the food. I was just about full and didn't feel too bad about it, since the dish itself is pretty healthy. 

OVERALL IMPRESSION: Great experience! I'm glad that I tried something other than pho. I will come back again for sure.
author: Wendy F.

description:
I ordered the bbh, such a disappointment no pork blood and why would give you fish cake for bbh? It should be cha hue or cha lue (pork cake). Bbh supposed to have the taste of
 lemongrass in the broth and the beef bone taste, but all I could tasted was beef canned broth. My husband ordered their Pho đc bit and was a disappointment too. Pho noodle is not chewing, no aroma of star anise or cinnamon. 

Note to the chef, you have Vietnamese customers too, so pls don't skim on ingredients just because no one said anything.
author: Katie C.

description:
Came here during lunch on a sunday before going to a show. When i came here, i assume that This place may vietnamese chinese own since there chinese letter on menu other than vietnamese wording. And they give you fortune cookies when you asks for your check. 

When you look at their menu, there are so many choices of food to choose from...appetizers, noodle soup, vermicelli, rice plate, vegetarian, and so on.

I decided to get bun rieu since it looks good base on the yelp photos and i havent had it for a long time. $8.95 for only 1 size. Kinda pricy. It consists of mostly fried tofu, tomatoes, shrimp, eggs...I like how it came out hot. I like the flavor of the broth, almost remind of home cook  bun rieu from home. 

Got busy after 1 on a sunday that they started doing the wait list so i got lucky that i came before the crowds started rolling in.

Service was average.

Will come back again in the near future
author: Julie N.

description: I got the vegetarian imperial rolls with vermicelli & the vegetarian fresh rolls for take out. Both made vegan ((ask for no fish sauce))! So simple but soooo much savory flavor, which is hard to find as a vegan in SF.  The person who took my order wasn't the friendliest but it looked like she had a long day, no big deal. Overall, highly recommend!
author: Devin T.

description:
Came here on a Friday night as a party of 7, no problem getting seats. 

I ordered the number 1 house special beef noodle soup, that came in a HUGE bowl, but the portion is actually just medium with lots soup. I was not starving but still have no problem finishing it. There were not that much beef/ meatballs/ tendon, and the few slices of beef were tough. The broth itself is a little blend, really not much flavor. It only look stunning visually when served in the huge bowl, but everything else was mediocre. 

My friends ordered the special combination plate and Bun tht nag with barbecue pork. I tried a little bit of the pork and it was delicious! it was tender, and grilled and seasoned perfectly, definitely not the rough over-cooked thick pork chops. The rice noodles were soft and fresh. When rice noodles are sitting out too long they get dry and break easily, but not the ones in Kim Son. The restaurant even gave them a complimentary bowl of chicken broth on the side! 

The pho was only average but the rice/ noodle plates were delicious! I will come back for sure to try the barbecue items but will skip on the pho.
author: Karen C.

description: The food here was alright. My fiancé is Vietnamese so I've been exposed to their cuisines. I ordered a steak rice plate and was presented with a slightly burnt steak. I'm usually okay with that but this dish had a strong methane gas smell to the food. My a fan of it. I didn't care to much for it so I barely touched it. My hubby enjoyed his cold noodle dish a lot but I wish that was that same for my food.
author: Sally L.

description: If you want dirty old food laying around to be cooked in the microwave this is the restaurant
author: Daniel K.

description:
Pho is killer, the broth is on point, has been great since I was a kid. For 20+ years I've been eating Vietnamese food, and this place does it well, consistently. My only gripe is the pickled jalapeños on the table have sometimes been left out too long and get mealy. 

Love this place and their new spring roll/bahn mi shop across the street.
author: Francesca S.

description:
Service : Very friendly and very attentive. 
Bathroom : 4/5 very clean (like spotless clean), one toilet per gender with communal sink to wash hands. 

Food was good here I ordered the #1, Pho Xe Lua, House Special Beef Noodle Soup. It comes with tripe, tendon, beef ball, fresh Slice beef and cooked meat. (You can have the option of the slice beef being raw serve on another plate). They have all the works at the table, jalapeños, fish sauce, chill oil, chili, siracha, and hoisin sauce. I can def taste the MSG but then you tell me a pho place that doesn't use MSG. At the end of the meal it comes with fortune cookies with ridiculous fortune ( always a wth moment with the cookies ). After you meal head on next door for some purple cow! (Around dinner time purple kow get busy - order before your meal and walk into the restaurant which they don't mind) 

Parking : tough for premium parking but if you don't mind walking park by the church there's plenty over there. 

Enjoy l!!
author: Sam T.

description:
Yummmmmmmmmm! 

Came here tonight after a day of hiking around The Marin Headlands. I was starvinggg. Parking wasn't difficult at all for a Sunday night. Although the bluegrass festival at golden gate park did let out the same time we were going to dinner.. 

Though it was busy, my gf and I got seated fairly quick. We actually had to share a table, but that's no big deal when you're borderline hangry. Yaddamean? They were pretty nice to sit with so it's all good. 

I ordered the #2 wish is the special combo pho. They use really delicious meat here. The broth was flavorful and tasty. It was not overly salty which is always a plus in my book. We also ordered some spring rolls. No wow factor there, but it was good! 

The guy in front of be got bun rieu. I was so hungry I didn't even see that on the menu. If I'm ever in the area. I want to try that next! 

One of the servers spilled ice cold water on my friend. ): but she was genuinely sorry.
author: Dianna C.

description: This place is soooooooooooooooo good! I came w/ my fam and everyone ordered something different. I had the Bun w/ bbq pork and it was so bomb. Moms had the chow fun & dad had the pho. Both legit 10 stars.  Love yourself, eat here.
author: Kessia R.

description:
The imperial rolls here are the BEST. I'm usually very critical on how imperial rolls are served at Vietnamese restaurants. Sometimes, it's too burnt or does not have stuffing. They definitely make better cha goi (imperial rolls/egg rolls) than me. Mine usually comes out burnt. Kim Son's egg rolls are crispy, chunky and well stuffed! 

The Bun Rieu on the other hand is not too bad. I might have to revisit Kim Son a couple times before I'm able to make a decision. The bun Rieu was extremely minty. The mint overpowered the broth and everything else in the soup. There was also a bit too much fried tofu. The bun Rieu meat tasted more like sui mai instead of the authentic crab meat mixed with eggs. Nonetheless, I still enjoyed the broth.

The service was quick and fast. The restaurant looked quite clean from the outside and the inside. The place was still relatively crowded at 2 pm on a Sunday. I'll be back to try other dishes that they offer.
author: Kathleen U.

description: I love this place! So blessed to have this joint in my hood. I always order pho tai with lemonade. Beef is always good quality and broth always hot. Service is fast and friendly and I hate Thursdays only because I know that's when they're closed and that's always when I want it
author: Alicia T.

description:
Another solid Richmond pho spot (watch out tenderloin) Came here for pho with my vegetarian fiancé.  I ordered the pho tai and she had the vegetarian pho. 

Pho tai
Broth 5 of 5
Noodles 4 of 5
Beef 4 of 5
Portions 4 of 5
Price 4 of 5

Vegetarian pho was unique and had a distinct flavor uncommon to most vegetarian pho's.  It was loaded with mushrooms and vegetables too which was another plus.  Overall I'd give the vegetarian pho 4 out of 5 stars.
author: Dan O.

description:
The serving size of their pho is much more generous in comparison to any of the Turtle Tower or Kevin Noodle House chains.  They only offer 1 size for pho - large, under $10. 
Hubby had the beef brisket with egg noodles. I tried the seafood thin noodle pho. 
I still think the broth at the other 2 pho restaurants taste better but the portions here will really fill you up if you're a big eater.  My seafood consisted of a couple of clams, fish cake, shrimp, squid with a platter of basil, bean sprouts, jalapeno and 2 slices of lemon to share between the 2 of us.
We also tried the fried imperial roll which was OK but the ones served at Kevin's is tastier.  My pho had so much green onions in it that I had to pick them out because it overwhelmed the dish. And I like green onions but not that much. 
In comparison, I prefer the broth at Kevin's or Turtle Tower.  For portion, this place is better given the price. Hubby tried my pho because I couldn't finish and he thought the rice noodles at Turtle Tower and Kevin's tasted better. 
Not a bad place for pho in the Outer Richmond, but not the best I've ever tried. Lunch for the 3 items came to $34 including tip.
author: Ry T.

description: We were craving Vietnamese after work one day and this place was close by so we decided to give it a spin.  No frills interior, decently clean, plenty of seating on a weeknight.  My wife got the BBQ pork and imperial roll rice plate ($8.95) and I got the pork and spring roll over vermicelli ($9.95).  Both were decently tasty and enough to fill us up, but nothing so outstanding that we'd go out of our way to make this a part of our rotation.  Solid, but not spectacular.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Ordered two bowls of pho (tai bo vien & tai gan) which only comes in one size, goi cuon, and goi ga.

pho - broth is good, rare beef was sliced thickly which made it chewy and difficult to eat, noodles did not stand out, generous amount of gan (tendon)

goi cuon - looked like a roll my brother would make...a bit rough on the edges and thin with almost enough filling; a few pluses, they make it with both pork and shrimp...the rice paper had a good consistency...and they boil the shrimp instead of steaming which imparts a very different texture and flavor; could have been improved with more greens (lettuce or herbs)

goi ga - sizeable portion, good nuoc cham (fish sauce dressing), this dish also would have benefitted from addition of herbs (mints, basil, etc)

The thought that came to mind as I dined was that it felt like I was at a relative's house, as opposed to my mom's. In other words, the level of care and quality of season just wasn't quite there but there was definitely effort nonetheless. In summary, ok place when in a pinch for Vietnamese food.
author: Cat T.

description: always a good place to eat some Pho ! fresh and clean and good broth quick service . you can enjoy the beach after a meal here
author: Gerardo G.

description:
Very good soup noodles, running from
$9-11/ big bowl. One size only.

Chicken pho and bun rieu ordered. Had I been hungry, would def have tried other menu items. Your standard, no-nonsense eating restaurant for Viet food.

Located one store space east of Purple Kow!
author: Jana C.

description: Best pho in SF. Locals know it as best. The family that owns it will remember regulars. Try to 5 spiced BBQ chicken (either rice plate or pho). Such a great hole in the wall spot or place to go for any night.
author: Eve L.

description: Great viet food in my neighborhood.  Can never go wrong with this place. The Bun Rieu is
author: Tim C.

description: I have just finished my second visit here, having tried the imperial rolls, and the barbecue chicken and beef.  My husband had a chicken soup with vegetables and rice noodles.  We think the food is excellent and a great value for the money.  We will be back soon.
author: David G.

description:
Local vietnamese restaurant shop run by Chinese/Vietnamese speaking family. Is it the best pho I've ever had...no... but it's solid on a cold and foggy day in outer richmond. I generally order the vegetarian noodle soup or the combination. Everything comes with the side of bean sprouts, basil, lemon and jalapeno peppers. The service is quick if not annoyingly quick that you feel like you have to get out.

A common favorite here seems to be the spring rolls which you can wrap yourself or order wrapped. The one downside is they don't give you that fried crispy roll that makes spring rolls so yummy. Something which I would consider giving an extra star just for that.
author: Linda L.

description: Incredible Vietnamese food. I got the bbq beef combo plate and it was truly delicious. I see why this place has so many stars! Yes go here!
author: Sara R.

description:
It's easy to take proximity to good ethnic food for granted, so I'm making myself write this review. I feel so thankful to live near good Vietnamese; I eat here almost every week. Flavorful (pho, ban hoi, the bbq pork, the bbq chicken, the fish, etc. - everything!), and super fast (especially if you order take out).

The ambiance is EHHH, but it's exactly what you'd expect from a divey Vietnamese spot. The tables are always sticky, and can't say they have any design sense whatsoever. But no matter: the food is tasty, quick, and reliable.

P.S. The owners' son just opened a banh mi place across the street - delicious, too. Cash-only which sucks but we probably all get our ATM transaction fees reimbursed anyway, through Schwab, etc. right? If not...what are you doing?
author: Nami S.

description:
Good Vietnamese restaurant in the Richmond district.

Good combination Ph with good cuts of meat. The vegetables on the side are always fresh.
author: Cm Tú Đ.

description:
We ordered two things:

Pork Chop & meatloaf over rice: When my rice plate came, there was no meatloaf. It was sold out. Instead they gave me an extra pork chop to substitute the meatloaf. It would be nice if they asked me before ordering. I had 3 pcs of pork chop on the rice plate. 2 out of 3 were not fully cooked. It's still pink inside. When I told the server, the response was "Okay, alright." No apologies whatsoever. 

Crab paste meatball soup noodles: I looked and looked again. There was only one crab paste meatball in the bowl. I am not sure if they were running low on crab paste meatballs for the night. They gave me a lot of tofu in the bowl. If they actually didn't have enough crab paste meatballs for the night, it would be nice if they told me before ordering. The soup was fully loaded with MSG. I was so thirsty afterwards and could barely feel my tongue.
author: J L.

description:
To be quite honest, I don't think I'm the best judge of Vietnamese food: give me a vermicelli bowl with tasty BBQ meat or a soul-warming bowl of pho, and my Yelp review will likely be a thumbs up (+/- snarky comments if I find something to make fun of)

Kim Son stands out beyond my typical vermicelli/pho complacency in two respects:

1) The vegetarian pho ($8) has quite a lot of ingredients, and it is not a sad bowl of regular pho minus meat as you might expect. There's tasty fried tofu that soaks up the broth as well as a good selection of veggies (broccoli, bok choi, carros, mushrooms. Who knew broccoli would taste so good in pho). For the broth, you can even choose vegetarian, chicken, or beef for pseudo-vegetarians like myself. I thought the chicken broth could have used more flavor (my gold standard is Turtle Tower's pho ga) and it was borderline lukewarm (or maybe I just spent too much time taking food pictures and it cooled down). Overall it was satisfying and refreshing, and the topping of fried garlic added a nice touch.

2) Their broken rice entree ($12) is essentially a sampler with 7 specialties, and it's a dish I've never seen at a restaurant before. One can scoff at the composition as a hodgepodge of miscellaneous items (or, as I've seen in another review, it's a peasant's dish of leftovers--hence broken rice--that ironically costs more here as a special). However I did appreciate the various textures and flavors, ranging from umami BBQ prawns and chicken, to the sweet shrimp-wrapped sugarcane, to crunchy classic imperial rolls. It also comes with an interesting egg thing (sort of like an omelette), a pile of shredded pork (reminiscent of sukiyaki), and a fried tofu skin roll (no idea what was in the filling but it was good). The concept reminded me of street food because you try bites of traditional, time-tested favorites. I can totally imagine myself nomming on a sugarcane shrimp on a stick while strolling in an open-air market. 

Kim Son very local business-y--a homemade cooking style and a family-run vibe, the server was a very friendly lady who looked like she may be the owner. The neighborhood is a bit out of the way in the Outer Richmond, and parking is not too impossible on weekends if you go for an early lunch (then you could beat the Purple Kow crowd too!)
author: Edna C.

description:
Long wait for regularPho. There's really nothing great about this place since there's always a long line, and it's more popular with the locals than other places, mainly because people think that if they pay one or two dollars more that they will get better food.

I think the portions are smaller than other places, and I think people come here because it's convenient but it's nothing special. I've had their beef and also their seafood noodle soup and I don't think it's worth the 45 minute wait.
author: Jackie H.

description:
One of the better Vietnamese restaurants in the outer part of the city.

My favorite item here is the Bun Rieu, which is crab tomato noodle soup. The broth is packed with flavor and they're generous with their portions. I really like their fried Imperial rolls too. They always come out perfectly crispy. I like how they have broken rice here, which is hard to find in the city. And you can never go wrong with their Pho.

I always feel welcomed when I come in here. The workers are nice and attentive.
author: Derek T.

description:
Exceptionally mediocre food in outer Richmond, though, it was, apparently the only thing that opens at 3 PM on a Sunday afternoon that is not a cafe, and it was also, a crowd pleaser, seeing how close it was to the beach. I found the restaurant to be oddly comfortable, because it's quite ethnic, and sort of speaks to the neighborhood it's in. 

I don't do the burbs aka the Avenues well. I see it more of an excursion, as in, I have friends to visit, and my friend wanted to go there. It's just one of those things, you go because your friend could not get you into a better place as it was closed. As of late, I find, that people sometimes try to impress me, they would remove their hoodie to wear a proper coat, because "you are stylish", and I think it's becoming so prevalent that I feel like telling them to stop, as I have become a bit too self conscious with the way I dress. And then it's the food. They want to impress me with their food selection. I like novelty, oddity and rareness. Not once but twice varies friends have taken me to Cockscomb, and so many had suggested Trou Normand, but here is the thing, I like good food, but I like my companion more, despite how they are dressed or where we end up eating at.

Kim Son is an excellent place to demonstrate such concept. It is the perfect place to eat mediocre food with some of your closest or new friends. The restaurant is open at all hours, even on a Sunday afternoon it's crowded. It's a straight shot from Inner Richmond to Outer, meaning, you don't have to waste your brain cell to figure out how to get there, if you are coming from the lower avenues. 

For food that is lackluster, it's fairy expensive, that part made me a bit uncomfortable and thus a reduction of rating. I'm perfectly good at shoving $20 for a good bowl of noodle soup, but a very typical pho is not worth the $9 they charge. It's just not that great. 

Here is the thing, if you really want to get a good bowl of pho, go to Oakland and San Jose, or stay in Inner Richmond, why bother with this joint? But sometimes we end up at a place because that's where we end up. We don't always control our immediate destiny, as you know. 

We finished the food. T liked his just fine. I had taken more than half of mine to go. And we headed out to see the sunset. Wait, here is the silver lining, sunset on Ocean Beach from this place is one minute drive, and not ten if you are coming from Inner Richmond. And your companion, is as dashing as one could be for a man in the late 40s: slim and tall, jacket and jeans, dark rim glasses and a beanie. Which, by the way, in case you are wondering, is the mandatory look and standard attire for all male Midwestern transplanters of a certain age.
author: Victoria E.

description:
OMG this is one of the best Vietnamese restaurants I've ever eaten at. I'm just visiting this week, but have eaten here twice already.  Extremely fresh ingredients and delicious grilled meat and prawns.  The owners and waitstaff are so sweet and accommodating.  I ordered the grilled meat and prawns with all of the vegetables and mint that you wrap into your own spring rolls, but I also tried their fried rice and fried Spring rolls.  They too were  exquisite.  The fried rice was evidently prepared on a very hot wok, so had that almost charred flavor with very little oil that you can only accomplish on a very hot wok.  The spring rolls were delicious with a good portion of pork in them and a fresh made dipping sauce. 
I would come here at least once a week if I lived here.  

I can't say enough about the genuine care the owners and staff put into this place. It's very admirable for people who were not born here to have made such a wonderful place to dine.  Thank you for sharing your culture with us and the freshness that is Vietnamese cuisine.
author: J A.

description:
Nice roomy vietnamese place with some chinese undertones, did anyone else see the giant chinese characters up on the wall inside?

They have a great selection of soups, broken rice dishes, and vermicelli. I ordered the bun thit nuong cha gio (aka rice vermicelli with grilled pork and egg rolls). The meat was a tad on the fatty side compared to how I've had it everywhere else. 

My final complaint is a tad on the picky side: they don't have fresh coconut juice! I was surprised that 1) they had a huge list of other typical vietnamese drinks, and 2) there was a photo of fresh coconut juice, but they don't serve it because their machine to chop off coconut tops was broken. So sad!
author: Christine L.

description:
This is my favorite place for pho in SF, maybe anywhere. 
Their veggie broth is incredible! I don't know how they get such great healthy flavor. A little basel, lemon, and spice gives it that perfect touch. 
Great ingredients. You won't find a better lineup for veggies anywhere. Extra mushrooms makes me extra happy! 
Love the owners and the staff! Friendly and authentic. I can't stand when someone puts on a fake smile. You're not having the best day. I'm glad because me neither! Thanks for not making me smile back at you. It's like mutual love and respect to my friends. 

Oh yeah! Veggie fresh roll can't be beat! 
Coconuts too! Nice. Little on the pricey side but hey.. Coconuts.
author: nick l.

description: The catfish clay pot is fresh, flavorful and delicious. #1 pho is a great staple, the steak cuts were tender. And there was a shrimp and coconut curry stir fry, I loved that too! Friendly service too. Tea is inexpensive as well (.45 each)
author: Mingming C.

description:
Kim Son is one of my favorite places in San Francisco for a bowl of delicious bun rieu!

I like to start with the deep fried imperial rolls.  Six rolls are filled with pork and deep fried with an incredible crunchy outside.  The rolls are served with a side of shredded pickled carrots, vermicelli noodles and fish sauce for dipping.

Then comes my order of bun rieu ($8.95).  The tomato based soup is served with vermicelli noodles, sliced tomatoes, fried tofu, shrimp, and a delicious crab patty.  Unlike most places, theirs doesn't come with pork blood (which I'm fine with because I don't eat that).  The tomato and shrimp paste broth is delicious, flavorful, and perfect for those cold days.  The bf likes his soup with a bit more shrimp paste, so feel free to ask them for a side of shrimp paste and add for your liking.  The serving size is generous and I have a hard time trying to finish my bowl.  

WHAT TO KNOW:
*Credit cards are accepted
*The restaurant is clean, food comes out in good time, and the older workers are friendly
*Variety of noodle soup dishes and a broken rice dish (a rare dish to find in SF)
*Closed Thursdays
*Street parking
author: Nicole S.

description: If you dont mind having limited -and in general not good- service in exchange of cheap and nice Pho, this is your place
author: Sara V.

description: Bbq pork rice plate was good but pass on everything else. We ordered #11 pho with bbq pork and imperial rolls - both nothing to write home about. Bland broth and rolls. Thai iced tea - think they forgot the sweetener. They were fast and nice though.
author: S C.

description:
It took me WAY too long to finally find Kim Son, I think I've found my new favorite noodle joint.  If I'm in outer Richmond and in the market for noodles, I'm here!

My experience at Kim Son was super chill, I felt like I was at my grandparent's and they wanted me to eat, and to keep on eating.  I tried their Bún bò Hue and it was loaded with meat and tasted great.  I barely put a dent in my bowl of noodles and I had enough to take home to save for another meal.
author: Sam K.

description: The best Pho in San Francisco.  Portions good and price is not bad.  Not too salty.  Great for families, friends....and bears from St Stephen's Delhi.
author: Mandi T.

description:
In reading the Yelp reviews, I wanted to try broken rice for the first time and based on the reviews, I chose this restaurant. We arrived at lunchtime 1pm on Saturday. All the tables were almost filled up. People were eating soup and clay pots which looked good. I ordered #25, the broken rice with two thin pieces pork chop bone in, baked egg with nice ingredients inside like glass noodles and looks like mushrooms? and shredded pork. And my friend ordered the lunch special with BBQ chicken, an imperial roll, salad and brown rice that comes with an interesting house soup with tofu and squash. I will go home and make a dish like that. It's a nice combination. 

Wow, the BBQ chick was plump, soft and flavorful! I will need to come back and order the chicken!! My friend enjoyed her dish and said it was really a lot of food for one person. I enjoyed my broken rice dish, but it was hard to get used to the texture of the broken rice because it is very fine and grainy and very light. This is just my personal preference, but others may enjoy it. Everything else on my plate I enjoyed and was happy with my order. Yes, it was a lot of food for one person. Didn't leave much room for dessert, so had to walk around the block. My friend and I will definitely come back to this restaurant in the future for they have so many other dishes that looked good. Service was good and food came timely. :-)

Funny to note that peasant rice dish (broken rice) costs more than regular rice. I was looking up what is broken rice. It is a lower grade rice made that way during cleaning when rice is harvested with not much nutrient value and makes rice it stickier.
author: Priscilla L.

description: Craved Vietnamese rolls and this place is pretty popular by the beach. This place is usually crowded but the staff is pretty efficient and super friendly. Loved their vegetarian imperial rolls, the sauce had a hint of lemon in it that made everything taste so much better. The spicy catfish is a must. Also tried the Kung pao chicken and lemon fish. I'd say their forte is traditional Vietnamese food, so I'd stick to those dishes in the future. Overall awesome Vietnamese restaurant in the outer sunset.
author: Linda H.

description:
We were in town for a gaming convention and it just so happened that family was staying in the area too. We came here for dinner on our first night there and I scored a parking spot across the street!

For our group, I ordered a couple appetizers for five adults and one child. The fresh rolls with shrimp were excellent and the cha gio which ended up being the best I've had outside of Houston! We also ordered chicken with onions and ginger, some mixed vegetables with tofu, and a large beef pho with tendon, brisket, and meatballs. The food was a hit and the flavours were spot on. I especially liked the chicken dish with ginger and onions - a nice combination on a cold night.

Our server was friendly and fast, bringing us extra napkins and water refills. If I lived locally, I'd frequent this place for my pho fix and for those times when I crave cha gio. Parking wasn't that bad, there were spaces in front and across the street, plus neighbourhood spots.
author: Kristine H.

description: Yeaaaaaas! Vegetarian pho in vegetable broth? That's what I'm talking about! Why hasn't someone done this sooner? Who cares. It exists now at Kim Son. And the veggies are fresh and firm- not sad and soggy. This pho knocks the socks off of the rest. And for less than $10! Wha-whaaaat? Kim and I (yep I went with Kim to Kim) each had a bowl and banchan tea. Our bill was $20. Stop it.
author: Tanya F.

description: Bun rieu and bun bo hue were born delicious and authentic. The homemade meatballs in the bun rieu was really good. I will definitely make the effort to come back here.
author: Hung Q.

description:
I'm visiting from the east coast and wanted to see how the pho in SF measured up to one of my go-to spots in DC. I arrived here 15 min before closing and service was so fast! We were seated immediately, someone came to take our order within 5 min, and our food was out within another 5-10 min. We ordered two pho gai tans and one order of imperial rolls. The portions are HUGE and I love it. Pho is served with a plate of toppings on the side (basil, jalapeños, lime, and sprouts). One of my main test for good pho is the flavor of the broth. This broth was great! My only complaints about the food was that the meat in the pho was sliced thicker than I'm accustomed to and was a bit over cooked. The imperial rolls also weren't as crispy as I liked but the filling was great. 

What I especially appreciated about this place was the service! We were served very quickly, our water glasses were refilled 3 times (very uncommon to ever get a refill on the east coast) and the owner was SO SWEET! Because we arrived so late we ended up being the last ones left eating in the restaurant as he was trying to close up. I felt bad and was trying to quickly finish my meal and get out of his way, but he very sincerely told us "Take your time. Don't rush" which I thought was great customer service. I would definitely come back.
author: Johanna H.

description: Great service and a good portion.  I will come again for sure when I crave for noodles.
author: Linda H.

description: Very good food and friendly service. I also got a bi cuon, which is a pork spring roll. I was very impressed with how good everything came out. I will come back to eat here again.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Discovered this place while in line for Purple Kow one night & decided to bookmark it to try one day since its nearby us.

It's a decent phó place. My fave thing about this place was that they have the sink for washing hands outside of the restrooms. Very great idea!
author: Amy C.

description: Friendly, fast service and huge portions but... the Bun Bo Hue was not that great. The soup was bland and missing the aroma and spice that is typical of the BBH broth. It tasted as if they took regular beef broth and added last minute mixes to make the flavor. Definitely didn't taste like an actual BBH broth stewing on the burner. They also used fish cakes, which is a first I've seen in this dish. Maybe they're not known for their BBH; maybe I should've gotten something else. In any event, don't get the BBH here.
author: Thao T.

description: Broken rice is good. The grilled chicken and grilled poor are only okay. Service is friendly. Tables are moderately clean.
author: Byron L.

description:
Delicious and inexpensive pho and bun. Always crowded but we always find a seat.
Young coconut juice in shell is delicious. Love the fresh Shrimp rolls. Good service always.
author: Martha N.

description:
This was a very nice restaurant for the food. I wasn't too much of a fan of their eggrolls. Don't get me wrong, I'm sure half the city will love it but for me, its filling is kind of.. soggy? It shouldn't be. Their rice plates were nice. The barbecue rice plate that I got almost reminded me of the day I came out of the womb in my Vietnamese village. Biting into the meat reminded me of the daily hunt. 

It was cool, but do I really want to feel like a hunter? Nah.
author: Vu N.

description:
So me and my boyfriend went on a date night there ( all the way from Novato) because the good reviews and guess what? I am disappointed.

We love pho and tried at many places and this place was the worst.

The food was okay , my boyfriend ordered the beef pho and it almost no vegetables in there, I ordered the veggie one and the tofu was the worst tofu in my whole life , I didn't even eat it but the I had fresh vegetables and nice dish that's why I think it's fair to give the two stars.

So my main problem not only the food. I am people person so I always look for the service. The girl who served our table took our order very quick and the order came quick too . After finishing beer (half hour later) no one came to ask if we need something else or if the food is good and actually we need another beer. So we just gave up and we wanted it to ask for the bill and we waited half hour more (really we were counting the time) while everyone else came after us they already done and went home. So we were wondering what's wrong , so a guy came and we asked for the bill so he call the girl to bring it with really rude tone and look , my boyfriend pissed off because it wasn't way to treat clients (we are really easy going and understanding), but we didn't like that the service is the worst ever, I think they should smile more and actually ask if the food is good or just maybe care more . My boyfriend refused to give a tip but I did because I hope they improve their service and food . 

I don't think we are going again there!
author: Noor M.

description:
I thought I found a decent pho place finally in San Francisco. My girlfriend and I have given this place many chances. 

Customer service varies here. 

Broth is perfect some days and on others, it's extremely sweet. When I say sweet, it's like sugar in a spoon.

What topped it was when we found a long piece of hair in our pho. Really happy they took it off the bill. This happened to me once at Kevin's noodle house on Irving street. I found a hair in my soup and they tried to make me pay. That was when I just left.
author: Brandon F.

description: Whether you're a vegetarian or not this place is bomb! The vegetarian pho is by far the best in the city and I've tried many! The vegetables and noodles taste like there cooked and sautéed separately before being added into a delicious vegetarian broth, all the vegetables retain there original flavors and they use a variety of Vegis which make it more interesting than your average vegetarian pho. Another favorite is the vegetarian spring rolls my goodness are they tasty. Again I've never had vegetarian spring rolls taste this delicious. I just don't know how they do it! I'll even drive for 20 minutes each way it takes to get there from my house. It's that good
author: Sam E.

description:
I went here just for the fact that there is a pho place near by my house. When I went, I was seated quickly, and was able to order fast. The food was OK. I definitely had better food. I usually go on 19th & Irving to Kevin's or PPQ and their food was a lot better. I remind you, I was the person who said "How can you really tell the difference in between pho anyways?" but oh boy, I was wrong. The soup was mediocre, I tasted a little bit of fish in my soup which was odd.

The reason I'm giving 2 stars is not only because of the food but also the service. The people that were on floor need to smile more forsure. They don't smile, they kind of slam the dishes and tea on your table, and what made me really mad was as I was waiting to get my check, I didn't get it for awhile. So then I went up to the cashier and said "Hi, I had #6 and hot tea." and she gives me this dirty look and goes "What? ugh." and she rolls her eyes when all I wanted to do was pay for my food and get my sick self back into the bed. 

I don't think I will ever be back again unless I'm super desperate.
author: Thai C.

description: I remember the first time I stop here. The friendly staff, and the open food court was inviting. My eyes were bigger than my stomach at that time. Everything was good especially the pho they have there but my favorite was the soups
author: Jinn T.

description: Got my 12k steps on and found myself in the Balboa.  I'm pretty much a Vietnamese food newbie--- so didn't  really know what to order.  Had the BBQ beef. Tasty, but not special- nice flavor though. I've  had better Imperial rolls elsewhere.  Place is  pretty plain.  Seems clean.  Nice staff.  Cool neighborhood to explore, worthwhile if you're in the area and the line at the dumpling houses are long.
author: R G.

description:
Went here for a mid afternoon snack (so, basically a meal) so I got the crab paste tomato soup. I thought the flavor was a little weird and on the blander side but it is your standard crab paste, so if you've had it before in any Asian dish that's what it tastes like, in soup form, and more watery. 

My friend got the pho. The pho bowl was huge! Much bigger than Turtle tower and other standard pho bowls. Didn't try it but friend said it was decent / nothing to write home about.
author: Inga C.

description: There's a large parking space around the restaurant.  I love pho, and the broth was wonderful.  Quite atmosphere.  I read epicsaga -- Infinity on my tablet while I ate dinner, and it was a wonderful time.
author: Seraphine L.

description:
Miki was closed across the street. My friend and I didn't want to travel far, and saw that Kim Son had 4 stars on Yelp, so I thought it would be a safe bet.

I don't know if Kim Son pays for Yelp reviews or what, but it was definitely not a safe bet! I got the pork rice plate with imperial rolls, and my friend got the pho ga (chicken noodle) soup. My pork was too salty! It also tasted rubbery! My friend's soup gave her a stomach ache and we had to end our night early. It was a sorry sight. 

The weirder thing was that there was one of those clipboards hanging on the door so you can write your name down and save your spot in line. The place was packed when we left, with people waiting outside. I don't know why anyone would want to go here, it was awful. Just go across the park and you can get yourself some excellent Vietnamese food. It was the same price also as any of the other places on Irving which serve excellent Vietnamese food. 

I had tried this restaurant on my summer break, and I'm very disappointed that I wasted one of my meals here. I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
My wife and I stayed in San Francisco on the second night of our 1 year anniversary weekend. It gets pretty chilly in the evenings in May, so it was the perfect evening for some soup. 
Being we both love Pho, we decided to research via yelp where the closest pho joints were. The search returned many options, so we decided to choose Kim Son's. 
It was quite the challenge to find parking, even on a Sunday evening, so prepare for that. The menu was typical for a Pho joint which brings a bit of comfort, because of the similarities, but lacks in originality.
Despite how busy it was, the food was quickly served and delicious. As we dined in, it was very steady with the number of customers which indicated quality and many recurring customers. This would qualify as a 3 star... slightly above average rating, however the imperial rolls were delectable, and larger than most other joints, which justifies an extra star.
I would recommend this place for a quality experience, and good portions at a very reasonable price.
author: Landon H.

description: Came during an off-peak time on a late Sunday afternoon. It's a massive amount of food for the price. Highlight was the beef pho.
author: Matt G.

description:
Pho soup is TOO sweet. 
Soup is very sweet. It taste like I an eating sugar. I do not like this pho. 
Beef is okay. Noodle is a little below average, but okay. 

I won't go here again, because soup is so sweet.
author: Ted S.

description:
I came here as a friend said the Bun Rieu here is the best.  We must have different taste buds cause I feel like the Bun Rieu at Y&Y is more tasty.  Don't get me wrong... the Bun Rieu here is good, but I wouldn't say it's the best.  Bun Rieu normally has crab meat mixed with ground pork.  Unfortunately, I didn't taste the crab as I felt like I was eating a regular pork patty.

I also tried their bbq pork spring rolls and bbq chicken spring rolls.  The spring rolls are good, but I think the pork tasted better than the chicken.  I was worried the chicken would be dry, but it was nice and moist.  However, it's pricey for what it is.  It's $7.95 each for four spring rolls (or 2 since it's cut in half).

Note:  They're closed on Thursdays.  Also, they accept credit cards.
author: Candice H.

description: It's pretty good. I've eaten here a couple times because it's only a 10min walk from my place. Service is ok, but the food is good.
author: Kendra O.

description: This used to be my spot to go to when I wanted to satisfy my Viet food cravings. Came back awhile ago and it's still the same. I like both their pho and rice plates. I always walk out full and feeling good about this place
author: Maggie W.

description:
Decided to give this Pho place a try with a couple of coworkers. I'm honestly not really picky when it comes to Pho because I feel like it's generally hard to mess up. But I did really enjoy this place. I ordered a plate of Pho with tripe/flank and an order of spring rolls. 

Food:
I absolutely dislike onions. And most Pho places forget when I ask for no onions, but this place didn't! I was so pleased. As far as the Pho, it was incredibly tasty. They only have one size but it was seriously filling only for $9. All of their plates have really good prices. 

Service: 
Our service was prompt and our dishes all came out nice and hot. Our waitress was really cute and friendly; she was attentive and polite. 

Atmosphere:  
It's a legit Pho place, so it's not fancy. It's a cute family owned restaurant with your typical Pho restaurant atmosphere. It has plenty of seating, which makes it good for big groups. Not the prettiest place inside, but the food is great, so who cares.

I'd def come back for a hot bowl of Pho if in the area.
author: Stefany Z.

description:
I came here for lunch yesterday and was not too impressed. I got their number 3 which is the sliced beef pho, and I did not like their broth or their meat. 

You know when you cook sliced beef in with the soup and there are little pieces of floating meat residue in it? I can't really describe it but if you have ever had hotpot and you dip the sliced beef in the continuing boiling soup, then you'll see little specks of things in the bottom of the soup from the meat. My soup was like that.

However my friends got the same thing, and their soup was clear and unlike mine. I really only took 2 bites. Maybe it was just that day...
author: Janet K.

description:
The South Bay Vietnamese restaurants have spoiled me rotten.  Now when I go to other Vietnamese spots, I can't help but compare and end up disappointed.  Kim Son - I apologize for being jaded.  

Stopped by for a casual dinner with a group of friends.  The place was packed but we only had to wait a short while.  KS is definitely a hole in the wall.  No frills, no service and can't say the cleanest.  This is on of those places where you don't even think about using the restroom.  Our table was situated next to a wall with stacks of dirty old boxes and random storage items.  The chair seat cushions were all destroyed and very beaten up.  You certainly do not go for the ambiance. 

That being said, you get what you pay for.  I ordered a broken rice dish with BBQ chicken.  Sadly, the broken rice wasn't true broken rice.  It looked like they just mashed it up on their own a little.  Chicken was thigh meat with skin on, overcooked and had a mushy texture.  Seems like it could have been marinating for too long.  This dish was $7.95.  Wasn't inedible but I wouldn't go back and order it again.  Other half had pork rice plate and nothing notable.  Friends had a variety of rice plates, pho and bun bowl.  I noticed they do give a lot of noodles but that's not saying much.

Overall, KS is one of those places you can go for a quick/cheap meal.  Quality of food isn't so great and taste is average.  Wouldn't go back given lots of other options for Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Liv A.

description:
II ordered take out, their number 56 appetizer. It doesn't say it's served with peanuts, just double checked the order to make sure everything was set and there were unfortunately peanuts. 
Asked the owner about peanuts, and she tried to not fix my order for me and just told me to "tell her next time"... Lol. 
Had to kinda look at the employee likes, "um.. I didn't pay  for food that I'm just going to have to throw out because I can't eat it"
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Havent been here for a while. Was in the neighborhood. Ordered 1 seafood chow fun and 2 cold noodles (bun) both no onions and cooked bean sprouts (reiterated twice). Came back 20 mins later to pick up and they said they ran out of the chow fun. First of all, should the kitchen communicate with the wait people when something is out? Had to wait another 10 mins. 
Came home and found both noodle dishes with raw bean sprouts and lots of green onions. Why write it down when it's not being read? Restaurant is cooked to order not chef's choice. What if ppl said no peanuts cuz they are allergic? They can kill someone! No wonder I haven't ate here for a while.
author: amanda t.
