description: Food was good. Not the best pho I ever had, but the price was good. I was a bit disappointed about the service. We ordered clear noodle soup and beef pho. Instead of getting the clear noodle soup, we got chicken curry soup which was good, but not what we wanted. When telling the waiter we didn't get the clear noodle soup, he awkwardly said the curry was the clear noodle soup.
author: Loren T.

description:
Kim Son is one of my favorite Vietnamese spots in the city.

First and foremost, the wait staff/service here can definitely be a hit or miss, especially during peak hours. The older servers are always very polite + attentive, but the younger wait staff can be quite rude.

That being said, Kim Son's food makes up for it. They have one of the more extensive Vietnamese menus in the city, with rice plates, noodle soups, stir fries, and plenty of seafood dishes. Food can sometimes take a bit to come out (~15-20 minutes if they're really busy) but it really is worth it.

I like ordering the Hu Tieu Nam Vang, the Bun Rieu, or the Seafood Pho on a cold day. 

It's very clean inside and plenty of seating.
author: Lauren C.

description:
"That pho place next to Purple Kow."

For the longest time, that was how I knew this place.  Not that I'm the only one it seems - my friends didn't know it was called Kim Son either until we walked in.  But hey, it's not the worst way to be known, especially considering how many people go to Purple Kow.  Plus, it's better to be known of than not to be known at all!

As far as the food goes, I thought everything I tried was just okay.  The IMPERIAL ROLLS my friend and I shared looked great on the plate and were perfectly crispy.  However, the taste was pretty typical, for better or worse.  Hard to get excited when it tastes the same as everywhere else!  Plus points for how the order included some vermicelli noodles though (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kim-son-vietnamese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=PVLnCtRAe3ohteKqsXLZCw#QUJ7HqOazs_TUd5wS2bR4Q).

Similarly, my bowl of PHO TAI GAN (Beef Pho with Rare Steak and Tendon) didn't make much of an impression either (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kim-son-vietnamese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=PVLnCtRAe3ohteKqsXLZCw#-MSrW39w4yLPfSQIwG9wQw).  The broth had some decent flavor to it, but it felt a little greasy/oily to me.  Still not bad though, and not as big of an issue for me as how light on meat and noodles my order was.  Maybe the size of the bowl made the portions seem smaller than it really was, but it seemed like there was a disproportionate amount of soup to the good stuff dropped in.

Although the food wasn't super amazing, it's nice how everything came out fast and was priced so friendly.  Kim Son may not be a place I set out to eat at again (parking can be tough at times), but they aren't a bad choice if you're in the area...or if you're looking to grab something to eat before/after a trip to Purple Kow.  You know, that place next to Kim Son.
author: Mike L.

description:
During a raining weekend we decided to pop in and try some pho here instead of our regular haunts.  Ordered two number threes which is the Chin Nam aka sliced well-done beef flank (no tripe).  The broth was oily and not clean of fats and oil.  Taste-wise it was not great.  The noodles were limited and the actual beef was five pieces.  The beef quality was low.  There was significant gristle and cartilage which should not be the case for this dish.  We eat pho on a weekly basis throughout the Bay Area traveling all the way to the South Bay and this pho was unimpressive. 

ADVANTAGES :
+ Quick seating despite being full.
+ Prompt service and polite staff.
+ Quick turn around for to-go orders.

DISADVANTAGES :
- Soup broth was not good.
- Low grade meats used.
- Very small portions. Do not go if you have a good appetite.
- Parking on Balboa is limited due to Purple Cow and Balboa Theater.

TIPS:
+ If you must visit park towards 38th Avenue and circle the adjacent streets for parking.
+ If you can handle a quick bus or drive in SF consider visiting Good Noodle Restaurant at 239 Clement between 3rd and 4th Avenues.  The food quality is better and portions are far more generous.

Your mileage may vary. Good luck!
author: Teddy ..

description: We are local and eat here at least twice a week for as long as we can remember (prob at least 8 years)! The best pho and spring rolls! My husband is part Vietnamese and says it's the perfect substitute for his mom's cooking (they are located on the east coast so we don't get it often). Steve and family that run the place are also so nice! A+!!!!
author: Jeffrey G.

description:
I love Kim Son - friendly service, good food, reasonable prices. 
Their plain rice is always really good. The Golden Child loves the fresh spring rolls, the imperial rolls, the bbq pork, and the vegetable fried rice. His dad likes the lemongrass chicken and pho w tendon and I like all of those things :).
author: Robyn C.

description: They have a large selection of viet food which I do appreciate. It was a cold windy day so I went for pho (haha). Good pho, a little over priced but the bean sprouts were the most fresh bean sprouts I've ever seen in my life!
author: My N.

description:
I have dined here once in the past.  During my most recent experience, I came here with a couple of friends for dinner on a Sunday night.  It was not too crowded, and the hostess told us to sit wherever we liked.  I ordered the pho with bbq chicken. 

The food came out quickly.   The pho was at best, mediocre.  The MSG leaves you exceptionally thirsty for water.  The bbq chicken, which was served on a separate plate was moist and full of flavor.  However, I will have to subtract a star for the presentation of the dish.  There were two pieces of feather still left on the cut of chicken about the size of a paperclip.  It was not attractive to look at.  It is a shame, because it was quite good.  Another factor for the low rating would be the temperature of the chicken.  It was served at room temperature.  

After we were done eating, as tradition, we played credit card roulette to determine who would be paying for the meal.  +1 additional star because I did not have to make my wallet sad.    :)

I would be willing to give this place another chance.  Next time I would try a rice plate or a crispy, pan-fried noodle dish.
author: Victor L.

description: Pho here is excellent. Found this based on friends' recommended. Service was fast and everyone there was welcoming.
author: Jer M.

description:
Loved the spring rolls, noodles, Five Spice chicken, veggie chow fun, chicken with lemongrass and chilis!

Service was just okay.  Took a long time to get tea and water refills.

I come here for the good food!  My favorite is the seafood egg noodle soup (#16?).  I get the regular size and add lots of fresh bean sprouts, jalapeno slices and lemon/lime.  The broth is flavorful and has lots of shrimp, calamari and fishballs.  If you have a big appetite, go for the big bowl.  It's huge!

Kim Son has the best sliced pickled jalapenos at the table.  I love it.  It's spicy and vinegary with just a touch of salt (from fish sauce?).  I'm guessing it's made here because I've never had this anywhere else.
author: Susan C.

description: Simple dishes similar to what come out of my mom's kitchen.  Pho broth is not my favorite but when I need a quick fix, it does the job.
author: Loius T.

description:
~ Review solely based on veggie pho ~

Best one I've had in the bay HANDS DOWN. 

The broth is very flavorful which is such a nice surprise after always being served hot water with vegetables and noodles and having it labeled as "vegetable pho."  I didn't have to add obscene amounts of hot sauce to make it interesting, it was already lovely. 

The array of vegetables that comprise the pho will surprise you as well as the kick ass broth.  There were tons of button mushrooms, sliced carrots, broccoli, fried tofu squares, fresh scallions, fried scallions, and even bok choy! So noms! 

The service is also fantastic here and they are super fast at bringing the food out.  

Vegetarians ya'll should come here for pho!
author: Christina L.

description:
There was an unpleasant waitress.
She has such a bad attitude, pissed off face, very scary looking, small, light brown hair, young but no smile what's so ever who looks like a really ugly owl has been constipated for 10 days, or something, may be her head turns 360 degrees.
I really had a bad experience here today.
I wont be back here again because the freckin' Bxxxx!
author: Nobu K.

description: they are one of the best vietnamese restaurants I have been to in SF! The portion, the flavor, the selections (some of us ordered the crab paste pho, which is not an option at most places), the price are all great. but whats most important is the vibe -- you could tell its a family restaurant with high standard for quality and integrity, that has history.
author: Shuting Z.

description: solid pho, especially the veggie version. my favorite veggie pho in the city. there isn't usually a wait either, though sometimes it is cold in the restaurant.
author: Vanessa S.

description: I love Kim Son! I feel so lucky to have a pho spot so close to my house. The service is great, everyone is so friendly and very quick to assist. Food always comes out less than 10 minutes after ordering with huge portions. I've always enjoyed the dishes I order, but now as a vegan, I was so excited to read they offer a vegetable pho with tofu and vegetable broth. It was delicious.
author: Senait H.

description:
Very yummy Pho! The place seems to always be full! It has fast service with lovely asian women to attend your table. 
The table has a variety of spices to give your food a kick. It is really fun to try all of them out.
author: Andréia S.

description: Best pho place I've ever been to in the country. I got the beef pho and it was incredible, the service was excellent and the atmosphere was awesome, this is a must try and is really good for couples or families
author: Alberto M.

description:
Mayra L. speaks TRUTH! Quick, cheap, and delicious indeed. A lunchtime combo plate of barbecued pork, imperial egg roll, rice, salad, and soup was super tasty, super filling, and super quick. All for under $10. A Vietnamese coffee was a delightful splurge too. 

A steady Vietnamese/Asian-heavy stream of business is also a good sign, and even if it gets a bit full, tables turn over fast.

Next time I'm in the neighborhood, I'm definitely coming back to try more on the menu - as well as more of the cafes and bubble tea shops nearby.
author: Vincent L.

description: Felt so satisfied after getting my lunch yesterday. They are a little pricey but the food is good! Had the canh chua and cá kho t yesterday and it was so so delicious! Tasted very similar to the one from Vietnam. Good job
author: Lana T.

description:
Omfg. I am so. Freaking. Full. We ordered: #50 spring rolls with peanut sauce, #13 Pho w/ prawns & BBQ Pork, #82 Spicy prawns with onions and spicy sauce, a side of steamed rice, and Vietnamese Coffee. We're about to BURST. With tip, we paid $43-ish. Oh god. So full. So good. So tasty. AND we packed our to-go boxes to the brim with leftovers. ... You guys, I'm stuffed. Time for a nap.

The 3 stars doesn't mean it's bad! We like this place, actually. We like Gordo's Mexican Food also, which we would also give a 3. I guess after you've eaten at enough places in San Francisco and around the West Coast, you get kinda selective with the restaurants you'd give a 4 and up.

Kim's is inexpensive, tasty, has decent service, and is super low-key/non-judgey. That's my kinda place for a lazy Sunday dinner. :) We'll be back!
author: Sherilynn M.

description: Tried this restaurant tonight and it was packed. Have to wait in line to get the table.  Ordered some regular dishes, the pho is okay not bad, the imperial spring rolls are good,the grilled chicken, beef and pork are good in general, the noodle with tomato based is interesting.  Overall is not will disappoint your stomach.
author: Raymond P.

description:
Came for the pho and I'm very glad that I did.  I love pho and knew that there had to be some excellent pho spots in this area.  
The staff wetter very friendly and they spoke good English. ..not that that matters but I just wanted to throw that in there.  I wanted pho with rare steak and prawns, which wasn't on the menu as a combination but of course they accommodated.  They actually liked the two together and said great choice. I absolutely loved the pho.  The broth was the best I ever had.  
Will return
author: Elease T.

description:
First place I think of when I don't want to travel far for quick comfort food. It's close by. If there's a need to drive, parking in that area is not so bad either. 

I am going to review the one and only one dish I order from Kim Son - Bun Rieu. So far it is one of the best Bun Rieu I've eaten in SF. For those who don't know, Bun Rieu is Vietnamese crab and tomato based noodle soup comprised of crab, eggs, tomatoes, and vegetables. Some places I've tried have their soup watered down, or different kind of noodles, or they skimp on the ingredients. Kim Son almost never let me down with this dish (especially when I purposely go there for it). The perfect amount of ingredients on their Bun Rieu ensures the perfect flavors and textures. My boys have ordered their chicken pho and beef pho so I'll leave it for them to review.

Always ask them for the shrimp paste to go with this soupy noodles. They don't normally bring it unless you ask.
author: Em T.

description: When we first walked in, there was a lady in the back yelling to sit wherever we wanted. Took someone 7 minutes before asking us what to drink, even though there was only 3 other customers in the restaurant. The food was pretty good and came in a decent amount of time, not a huge fan of the egg rolls though. When we finically finished eating, we tried getting the attention of a lady and her response to us was "what?", pretty rudely. We waited for 10 minutes and still didn't get the check. Needless to say, the younger gentleman provided better costumer service.
author: Rowena Anne B.

description: I have my favorite places for bun rieu, but I still like to venture out and try other ones. I've heard good things about this place so I was interested in trying it. We came in on a Saturday afternoon so it was busy but didn't have to wait. Ordered right away because we all wanted the same thing. Food came out fast and it was the moment of truth. The soup taste test. Unfortunately it did not quite meet my expectations. I even added tons of fish sauce to give it some flavor but it just wasn't happening. The soup was more on the bland side and taste more like pork than crab. The pork meat in it wasn't that good and was fairly small and lacked flavor. They do put a lot of the fried tofu which I picked out. I probably wouldn't go back for this but if I did I would probably try their regular pho if I'm ever in the area.
author: Tiff C.

description:
They don't play around. Noodle soup sizes are HUGE,  a little TOO big for me [insert annoying "that's what she said" quote here]

Bun rieu is effing delicious but it's missing pigs blood yo! I couldn't even eat half of this thing because it's so big. My siblings had a #1 (so big it reminded me of the pho challenge) and a rice combo plate. Took a bite of each,  pretty good. 

They accept cards which is great.

This is a no frills type of place. Sit down, eat, stfu and leave please.

Tons of teeny bopper spillover from Purple Kow and they are SO OBNOXIOUS. Bring ear plugs if you don't want to go deaf from shrieking adolescents.
author: Susy C.

description:
We've been here a few times for their Vermicelli bowls. I usually get the pork one with the imperial roll and it's a good, filling meal for about $10! 

The portion is huge, so next time, I think, between 2 people we'd get one bowl and then a smaller dish and share. 

We also love the Thai iced tea. 

There's always aggressive fruit flies around here though, they should do something about that. Not the friendliest service, but not rude by any means.
author: Emma M.

description: I don't understand these ratings at all. Perhaps I should've gotten Pho, but the four dishes we ordered unfortunately all struck out, and you know what they say: "Three strikes and you're out!".  First, the veggie spring rolls were unappetizing and saggy with soy sauce dip. Second, the lemongrass tofu with green beans had some suspicious weird white matter which I can hopefully surmise as uncooked cornstarch.  Third, the combo broken rice dish with grilled pork and egg meatloaf ... I can't blame my toddler for not wanting it either. While I can't put my finger on what was wrong, there was definitely something and I had better. By the time we got to our fried banana with coconut ice cream, I gave up and sent it back to the kitchen for raw batter inside. Definitely not worth the wait or the effort to try - I could've done better in my own kitchen.  It's one of those baffling experiences leaving you wondering how it could all go oh so wrong in the kitchen!
author: Jenny W.

description:
One of the best tasting Vietnamese places I've had in the city for sure.  Line was very reasonable and so were the prices. 

Broken. Rice dish combo was very good as was the pork with vermicelli. 

Service was fast, especially taking into account the number of staff. 

This place isn't fancy but will get the job done if you're hungry and want something tasty.
author: Shomik C.

description:
Meh. I still miss Pagolac in the tenderloin. We ordered 3 different things and all were fine. Nothing spectacular but cheap and not terrible. I probably wouldn't eat there again unless I felt like celebrating the beauty of the mediocre. 

Very nice, real staff. Fast service.
author: Mario T.

description:
Like most asian places, they're fast, they speak their own tongue with no care in the world, and if you're lucky, the food is phenomenal. 
Being viet I thought this place was alright but my BF thought this was the best place ever and would not mind the drive back (the whole 45-1:00 if we don't hit traffic)

We both just ordered the pho but I'm giving this place good ratings on behalf of my bf and the wide selections of viet cuisine and not just pho. They had bun bo hue, bun rieu, com tam, bun nuoc mam (spicy beef noodle soup, seafood soup, broken rice dishes, dry vermicelli with fish sauce) and an array of other dishes that i love love love. There's something here for everyone!
author: Katherine L.

description:
I usually rely on my friends and admirers for good places to eat. Most of them, who obviously ate here, rated this Vietnamese restaurant at least a 4-star. I definitely must check out. 

I came here for my evening lunch. From the menu, I ordered the Special Combination Rice plate (highlighted on the menu): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/C7e1ZvLk-X3vGmZj5fuUAQ?select=c9Fv_4RK1iMj6Vm5nhFjdw

For $8.95, I get a choice of meat (I ordered the grilled beef) with one egg roll, vegetables, a heaping scoop of rice and the customary dipping sauce. I also get a bowl of house soup with the rice plate and that was pretty salty. "It was not a good start already."

When I get my rice plate, the beef was a bit dry and a workload on my denture. Thus continuously chewing and chewing the meat. Rice Plate: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/C7e1ZvLk-X3vGmZj5fuUAQ?select=ipCb_GLcyOH_bSnmeLFPyw

However the workers were very nice to me, even with my uniform on. But I wish my rice plate were just as good. 

I'm very generous in rating my reviews. But I reasonably need to disagree with many of my friends and admirers who enjoyed eating here.
author: Matt G.

description:
update: It pains me, literally pains me, to be forced to update this review, but I have no choice but to do so...

About half the times I've been here in the past 6 months, the pho broth has been lacking- sometimes horribly. I suspect when they think they'll be busy they water the broth down a ton.

It's super depressing. I go in expecting the legendary pho broth that won my heart, and these days more often than not get something so watery and devoid of rich flavor that I feel absolutely crushed and ripped off that I spent my hard-earned money here.

The Imperial Rolls are still exquisite! 

But still... There's been way too many times when I've picked up my spoon and felt immediate complete disappointment. 

 

Definitely the best pho in SF. Exquisite perfectly cooked and flavored imperial rolls!  Very loving and gracious staff. A true value for your money. The broken rice plate is also very good. I love the pho tai Nam.
author: Grizzle J.

description:
first time trying bun rieu, and I loved it!!  the broth is tasty and not too salty. it has mixture of sausage, tomato chunks, shrimp and tofu. If you like shrimp/crab paste kind of taste then this soup is to try for.   

I think I found my new favorite Vietnamese noodle soup ;)
author: Jacqueline J.

description:
This is more of a 3.5 star review. I've been coming here for a few years now, and in general, I really like the place. There's usually no wait, the food comes fast, and the place is clean. I generally order pho, because their broth is fragrant and servings are pretty big. Ex: The #2 combo is listed as a small, but it'd be a large size anywhere else. (Bonus: ask for the beef on the side for $1.)

Service is polite and quick, but minimal. I've yet to have my water refilled without flagging down a waiter, and I'm not a fan of cost-cutting measures such as having to ask for extra napkins. Lately, I've also noticed the meat portions shrinking in my pho orders. A few days ago, my #2 came with one meatball sliced in two. If I were to venture a guess, there may be pressure to reduce costs due to things like increased rent from the recent redevelopment of this Balboa corridor.
author: Andrew L.

description: When I'm feeling under the weather, the curry chicken soup never fails to make me feel well again, especially after a long day of work. Recently tried the Bun Rieu, too, based off reviews here, and enjoyed it very much. Kim Son is one of those places that makes a neighborhood feel like home. I am very happy with my dining experience here.
author: P N.

description:
Kim Son is a small family run Vietnamese restaurant in the Outer Richmond district of San Francisco. The restaurant is known best for their pho, a Vietnamese noodle soup, but also serves up a variety of Vietnamese cuisine including seafood, Viet BBQ, rice, and noodle dishes. If you are in the area and looking for a delicious Vietnamese lunch or dinner on the cheap I would HIGHLY recommend coming to Kim Son. 

The prices are low, the food is good quality, and you will always leave full (often with leftovers). What more could you ask for? 

Favorite menu items:
1. Chicken coconut curry noodle soup: Just as its name describes the dish is a hearty, creamy, spicy broth of coconut milk, chicken stock, and curry served with whole pieces of chicken thigh, rice noodles, with bean sprouts and mint leaves to garnish. $11
2. Imperial rolls: Crispy and delicious! Stuffed with a mixture of chicken, shrimp, and vegetables and served with a tangy vinegar based dipping sauce. $7.25
3. All day BBQ Combo plate: Comes with small soup, side salad, "broken" rice, and your choice of BBQ chicken or pork. $10 
4. BBQ Chicken & Prawn Pho: Exactly like its name suggests a Vietnamese Pho soup served with BBQ Chicken & Prawn comes with bean sprouts and mint leaves to garnish. $11
author: Tomas K.

description: This restaurant is good. I ordered the catfish claypot, It was so good and the Thai ice tea was good as well.
author: Ngân N.

description:
Came here for dinner earlier with some peeps. We were seated right away and the first thing that caught my attention was the variety of food they have. Everytime I go out for some pho I always order the same thing (beef & beef ball soup noodle soup) so I went ahead and ordered that.. 

All of our food came out pretty fast which is good. Service was pretty good, the place is nice and clean, and the food was satisfying.

4 stars it is.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Great vegetarian pho! An abundance of veggies and the perfectly crispy-on-outside, soft inside tofu in the soup. 

And, there's an entire section of vegetarian options on the menu, for those seeking veg...

The place is no frills but the food really hits the spot. Come on your own, in a small party or larger group / family - they have a few circular tables with lazy Susan's for easy family style dining.
author: Angela W.

description: Awesome Vietnamese restaurant in Outer Richmond. The rice combo plate was really good. The pho is pretty solid. I've also had the curry chicken noodle soup. It's very curry-y and doesn't have a lot of coconut milk. Imperial rolls were some of the best I've ever had. Definitely want to try the broken rice next time!
author: Sherry L.

description:
Stumbled upon this place & it smelled great, so we gave it a try. 

We were starving, so started with the fried prawn rolls. They were quite tasty. 

Next, we shared the first beef phô on the menu & the pork combo dish (#25). The phô was delicious with huge portions!

The pork....was phenomenal!! I ordered it base on many reviews of the pork. Honestly, when it came out I felt a bit disappointed. It looked like a flat, overlooked piece of meat. But, then I tasted it & wow...that's good pork! Seasoned to perfection. There was some sort of egg cake on the plate too, that was very tasty. ;)

All in all, not the best out of my phô place, but quite decent & very friendly, prompt service.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
I'm very disappointed to be writing this review but I didn't think Kim Son was anything spectacular, especially at the prices they were charging.

The service is great and friendly, if you don't speak Vietnamese, they may not understand you very well. But they were super courteous and warm. Here's one absolute thing to note: none of the Vietnamese people I saw in there at the time were having Kim Son's noodle soups. I also found their noodle soups on the lower end of the spectrum.

I ordered the Bun Rieu, the SO went with the regular pho. While the beef pho's soup was flavorful, it lacked the punch of a good soup base. It didn't have that long drawn out flavor, it was much too light and only good enough. Barely formidable against the pho noodles, which completely drained out the taste.

My Bun Rieu? Was relatively laughable. It was bland and I felt like I was putting it away, just to be putting it away. The SO didn't think so poorly of it but I guess growing up in a Vietnamese family changes my palette.

The BBQ spring roll was actually really good. The meat was perfectly cooked and the sauce complemented it endlessly. It was one of the best BBQed meats I have ever had.

As far as noodle soups go, I probably won't be interested again. I might come back to have a sit-down family dinner if I ever come back, it looked delicious when the table next to us received all of their food but if I had a pho craving... I might just have to sit it out.
author: Winè C.

description: It's been pretty cold and rainy here in SF, so we decided a nice warm bowl of pho would be nice. We came here cause it was the closest and it turned out being ok. I got the #10 which is a veggie pho which hardly had flavor. I kept having to add more soy sauce and hoisin sauce. Some of the servers seem very blah towards you as well
author: Johanna F.

description:
I live across the street from Kim Son and love heading over for pho on a cold San Francisco night. I have only tried pho at a couple other Vietnamese restaurants, but Kim Son is by far the best. The broth is DELICIOUS. I've tried the chicken and beef, and loved both of them. I also tried their Spring Rolls and have no complaints. I am a picky eater, but I always manage to finish their large portions. 

The only reason I took off one star is because the decor is nothing special. I have been to some very cute, trendy pho places, while Kim Son is sort of just plain. But their delicious food makes up for it!!
author: Dawn M.

description:
Been here since childhood.  dont quite remember if it taste quite the same but kim son is definitely a neighborhood find!  inexpensive, yummy vietnamese food.

they have a lot of options from pho to rice dishes to other noodle soups not found in other restaurants.  #24, bun rieu, was delish and loaded with stuff.  it is a specialty noodle soup that not everyone can make well.

used to come at least once a week...hope the tradition carries on!
author: Linda T.

description:
Love the raw beef and they don't skimp out. I get this every time I come. 

Bun Rieu is alright for a quick fix.
author: A W.

description:
Didn't feel well and I wanted some soup since I hadn't really eaten food for two days. Called my friend and they suggested coming here. Parking can be fairly tricky in this area (even around 7:30PM), so hopefully you're lucky! They also get packed quickly so you might have to wait a little bit.

My order:
Bun Rieu: ($8.95) Crab Tomato Soup
Cafe Sua Nong (Hot Vietnamese Coffee)

I love bun rieu but here, it was such a major disappointment! Their soups are a great value since they are so large but it was lacking so much in flavor. The soup base was extremely watery and I barely tasted any crab paste or tomato (though I know there was some because of the coloring of the soup). The chunks of egg and fried tofu was something I'm not used to in my bun rieu either. Maybe they use it to distract you from how mediocre the soup base is? I really didn't want to finish but I hate wasting food. I took the rest to-go so that a family member could possibly eat it if they wanted (or I can tweak it at home to make it taste better).

The cafe sua nong was nice and strong at least.

Service was "eh" since they got my order wrong. I ordered in Vietnamese and pointed at the item on the menu for her to see as well (the very last item on the menu). They still managed to bring out the wrong dish. In addition it took several tries to flag them down for the check and to get a to-go container. They're fairly busy though so I can understand.

I'd give this place another shot, but not for Bun Rieu. Never ordering that from here again! I make it way better.. :/

Minimum $10 for credit cards
author: Kitty K.

description:
Kim Son is my main go-to Vietnamese joint in SF. 

I'm Vietnamese so I'm pretty picky about main dishes that I'm used to having at home. 
Kim Som makes one of the best bun rieu I've had in SF - their portions are definitely generous (I always end up packing the rest to go). 
Once in awhile I'll get their bun bo hue (spicy pork noodle soup) & I love that it's actually spicy & hearty.
I really like their rice plates (specifically the Special 7 sides rice combo plate) as well - not THE best but still well-portioned & better than most SF joints. 

If you want good, big bowls of hot soup or traditional rice plates that remind you of home, come to Kim Son!
author: Sylvia N.

description:
I love this place! Rather this place made me love pho!  I wouldn't eat pho until I came here and got the wonton soup, it's by far my favorite soup. 

I came to day and got #41 which was the crispy noodle seafood, veggies and chicken dish it was amazing it's very large and I could only eat a little but have plenty for later. 

Thai tea was amazing as well, little pricy but overall good. I would highly recommend this place especially if your in the balboa area.
author: Veronica V.

description: We ordered the "Today Special" (tasted just OK / won't order again) & "Bun Rieu" (tasted a lot of msg).
author: Wendy L.

description:
Highlights
- Since it is right next to Purple Kow (My favorite milk tea joint!), it gives me an excuse to grab lunch and pay a visit to get boba next door. :)
- My quest for the best bun rieu (crab and tomato noodle soup) continues and this is a place that serves this dish, but I recommend their chicken pho here instead. It's one of the better pho places in the city in my books. Flavor and quality white meat chicken. 
- They also serve my favorite canh chua (sour soup) with shrimp at a reasonable price and it's tasty with a side of rice. It comes with a hefty amount of veggies: tomato, pineapple, bean sprouts, basil, celery and lotus stem (?)
- Never too crowded and I never had to wait for long for a table. 

Improvements
- Rice dishes are alright, but they do offer a wide variety
- Egg rolls are a-okay, nothing to rave about
- Shrimp spring rolls are typical with a lot of bean sprouts, noodles, and lettuce

Tips
- Call in your order to go, go to Purple Kow next door to get some milk team, and viola your food is ready!
author: Tracy T.

description: One of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in the outer Richmond area.  It doesn't just serve pho like some Vietnamese restaurants but has a variety of dishes.  I am Vietnamese but rarely eat pho when I go to eat any Vietnamese Restaurant, so I always order their rice plates with the imperial roll.  All dishes are under $10 not including tax which is a bargain because of the amount of rice, meat and large imperial roll.  I recommend anyone to at least try it, but recommend to come between 11-12 to avoid the huge crowd that comes in after 12:00 pm.
author: Kevin T.

description: This place is the only Vietnamese place where I can get vegetarian options.  I ordered their flat noodles with tofu and veggies and it was a plate full of tastiness.  I also got the Thai iced tea which was good too.
author: Vira P.

description:
Going to a pho place and not getting pho? Blasphemy! But when I saw the menu I got hooked on the idea of trying something new. I got the imperial roll BBQ beef combo and it was really good! The beef was cooked so it had a really nice, subtle "grilled" taste, and the sauce that it's served with added a great splash of flavor to it. What they serve you actually looks better than the pictures, too, which is pretty rare. Lots of food, great sauces, and plentiful seating. It appears to be pretty popular too which tells you something. 

It is on the pricey side for this neighborhood, though. It's the most expensive pho I've seen, actually.
author: Chris S.

description: Delicious pho and very nice staff. This place is just up the road from my house and we come frequently.
author: Nick S.

description: 2 starts for being basic & food price not worth it. Their vermicelli is too undercooked and the bbq is okay but meat looks like beef jerky, was unpleasant to eat. The workers didn't even address me when I came in, I kind of had to ask for help. Like I was the one bothering them. but it's okay. Not going to come back. Sucks that they're not that great, because there isn't that much Vietnamese places around here. Looks dirty too.
author: Camille B.

description: The best veggie pho! The broth is so tasty and not filled with sugar. It's savory and makes you feel amazing afterwords. The veggie imperial rolls are bomb too. Haven't found a place that beats the veggie pho here :)
author: Olivia K.

description: Third time ordering from Kim Son and each time it's more disappointing. It's suppose to be known for quality and quantity, but both have gone down. It's sad when you can count the pieces of meat given in a dish and the onions and whatnot become the focal point. It's pretty clear this restaurant is becoming like the other hole in the wall places where they'll charge up, but the quantity goes down. Will not recommend and will not be returning!
author: Peggy L.

description:
Hands down one of the best Viet restaurants I've been too and I don't find it easy to say that about many places since I usually get my fix off Viet food at home (which Id have to say is the BOMBEST everQ!!). Truly a hole in the wall. And trust me when I say, I KNOW MY VIET FOOD! (Favorite of all time)


We first ordered the appetizer (Imperial Roll) dish which was 6 egg rolls. Boy was it delicious. Porked filled egg rolls which a perfectly golden crunch it, served with a side of pickled carrots, lettuce and topped it off with some fish sauce.


My go-to meal is the daily special which was the broken rice dish with charbroiled chicken, shredded pork, grilled shrimp, and sugar cane battered with shrimp-like crab cake around it. couldn't stop myself from devouring this dish of greatness and it left me wanting moarrrrrr!!!! The combination of each little things on this dish compliments each other too well! (That's how Viets dooooo it, yay-yuhhhhhh!)


I managed to sneak a couple spoons of my friends pho broth. You can usually tell the quality of the pho based on the broth. (It's all in the broth babyyyyyy!!!!) when you don't have to add excess HoiCin sauces or additional sauces to the pho, you know it's on point!!!! Especially when you can tell there's not a ton of MSG in it either!

I would definitely recommend trying all three that I mentioned above!
author: Ricky L.

description: We ordered carryout.  Had the bun rieu, pho ga, claypot catfish, several other items.  It's solid.
author: ange c.

description:
After hiking around Lands End it was time for some lunch and pho sounded pretty good.

We arrived around noon and parking was pretty hard to find. It was kind of lame that the meters make you pay on a Sunday because I'm pretty sure most places let you park for free on Sunday... Oh well at least we found a spot. When we walked in the place was packed and VERY noisy. We had to wait 5 minutes or so for a table to open up but once we were seated menus and ice water were brought to us immediately. 

I ordered the BBQ pork with rice noodle soup and my boyfriend had the beef and tripe pho. We also ordered the Imperial rolls to start off with which were delicious! Definitely order these, they give you five or so small rolls with a great sweet sauce and some yummy shaved carrot on the side. I was a bit surprised when my pho came out because they served the pork on the side, but after I tried some of the meat I was happy they didn't put it in the broth because it would have messed up the flavor. The meat was really yummy but the broth was a bit bland. At least they give you a bunch of noodles! My bf thought his was okay, the portions are big but the broth left something to be desired. 

Service was fast and the food is so-so. Overall not bad but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
author: Sam F.

description:
Good Viet food in the city. San Jose Vietnamese joints are generally much tastier, but I'd come here again for noodle soup and cha gio.

Came here before visiting the Legion of Honor museum which is very close by.

Bun rieu (crab tomato soup) was decent, not too oily. Did ask for extra shrimp paste (mam ruoc) which helped give it a bit more funk.

The broken rice was OK but not anything close to Com Tam Thanh in San Jose / Milpitas. Not real broken rice - not as dry, so doesn't absorb the nuoc mam as well.

Also the tau hau ky was made from fish instead of shrimp - and had filler ingredients like water chestnuts. 

The cha gio was made from rice roll wrappers instead of wheat/egg flour wrappers, which is similar to what Jasmine Garden also does. Like that it makes them a bit crunchier / have a rougher texture for absorbing fish sauce.
author: Annie M.

description: Tasty & authentic food, generous portions & affordable. Staff were kind & attentive. Parking was reasonable. Would go again.
author: T S.

description: Was seriously craving pho after a weekend of bad eating, and this very much hit the spot. I ordered the #1 house special pho, with beef on the side and no onions. I didn't realize their large would be so large! Just because at other places, a large is more like a regular size bowl... well, 'Murica. The broth was on the saltier side though, so I just enjoyed the meat and the noodles. The beef was great; even at other places when I order it on the side, it gets a little dry once it's cooked, but not here. My friend and I also ordered egg rolls and they were wonderfully crispy.
author: Kathy L.

description: Ordered the beef pho with beef slices and beef ball man the broth was so delicious. broth was so good I burnt my tongue and didn't care it had so much flavor with onions and rice noodle didn't even need to add sauce.! I ended up finishing the whole thing and end up being super stuffed and satisfied. first time trying pho great experience will definitely come here again.
author: Bryan P.

description: I will start off by saying that the food itself was reasonably okay, not bad. But the service was awful. I was with 2 friends and they brought out one of our orders within 5 minutes of placing it, and then completely forgot about the other two orders for another 20 minutes and we had to remind them to place it again, because they clearly forgot. To top it off, we got the bill and split it 3 ways. Instead of charging me $15, they accidentally charged $125 to my card and gave me the receipt to sign. I understand mistakes happen, but instead of fully refunding me, they refunded me for the $125 and brought me a new bill for $15. Outrageous. No concept of customer service. Just want to squeeze every penny out of people but don't want to make their customers happy.
author: Priya V.

description:
Acceptable bun rieu for a pho place in richmond/sunset.  This is no way 4 stars if you compare it to the likes of pho 2000 in terms of price and portions.

What they do offer here that is unique is the wraps similar to 7 course beef and the catfish clay pot which very few vietnamese restaurants offer.
author: Allen T.

description: The imperial rolls were great, but the beef in my pho tasted like it was from McDonalds, and the pieces of chicken in my friends bowl were too big and looked disgusting.
author: R D.

description: Pretty good pho on a rainy day. Prices were OK might be a little higher than other pho places but not breaking the bank here. Nice location next to the Balboa theater. Clean. Efficient service. Hope they can provide more than 3 jalapenos for 2 people to share.
author: Carol L.

description: I would highly recommend this place. Three people can eat for less than $35 for dinner. The food is outstanding, the wait staff was extremely friendly and the portions are huge. I have the crab and tomato soup which was great, my wife had a chicken noodle dish which tasted fantastic, and there is plenty of vegetarian options for our vegan friend
author: Matthew S.

description:
This place is LEGIT!!! I've had my share of pho at many different restaurants and this is def high on my list. This seems like a hole in the wall, family owned place with very nice and homey employees. I always get the pho dac biet, but I ordered the small since I saw that the large was HUGE... like easily shared between two people. The small is pretty big too and I couldn't even finish my bowl. That's saying a lot since I pretty much ALWAYS finish my pho.

Their ingredients are fresh and they really do give a lot of the meats and not just a ton of noodle. I actually found my bowl to have more meat than noodle! My friends said that their broth tasted like MSG, but you know what? Pho and MSG kind of go hand in hand IMO so that doesn't bother me.

Oh, and the boba place next door looked so good, but the line was SUPER long the whole time so I didn't try it... Maybe next time...
author: Lillian C.

description: Delicious bbq pork with rice noodle Pho and imperial rolls!  You can always get the special combo which is a DYI roll option: you get both the imperial rolls & pork plus sugar cane shrimp, vermicelli noodles, rice wraps and lots of fresh veggies and add-ons. Great food for your buck!
author: Sandy T.

description: located right next to purple kow.  that says a lot right there.  get your drink and then come in for some pho.  perfect combo.  lots of high school kids come here for lunch.  gets pretty packed.  the pho is pretty good.  not the best not the worse.  i think this place is just a pairing for me with purple kow.  when i say purple kow i say pho right next door.  its set in stone in my brain.  prices are reasonable.  service is fast as all pho places.  goes better with boba than the pizza place across the street.
author: Matthew G.

description:
Imperial rolls- yes do get! One of the better ones in the bay

Bbq chicken w pho- tasty. Pho is good/filling

#1 beef special pho-large, aunt and mom did not like.. quality of ingredients was meh and salty according to them.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Amazing Food! Love the pho, imperial rolls,spring rolls and vegetable fried rice!  Best Pho you will ever have. This is literally my favorite place to eat!
author: Jalaya F.

description: Can't go wrong with the quality of home cooking, great prices not yet taken over by the "new" SF... Steve is so humble along with the rest of them.
author: Casey K.

description: Bun Rieu was really tasty. Lots of crab, egg,  tofu, and tomato. It was my first time having it so I wasn't sure what to expect. It was pleasantly delicious and just what I needed since I have a cold. It was unbelievably hot though. So proceed with caution! I've eaten here once before, ordered a rice plate and found it way too salty. I'm glad I gave this place another chance. I'd definitely get the bun Rieu again.
author: Rochelle I.

description:
Nobody at the front of restaurant so we had to seat ourselves. Then I got a menu literally flung at me. 

I got the seafood chow fun, it was really saucy with barely any chow fun. My bf got the house pho and the meat I tried was good.

Overall I wouldn't come again, just because I am really big on good service.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
This is solely for the combination beef pho noodle soup (item number 2 on the menu).

The bowl itself was a good size, filled with proportionate amount of noodles and beef / other beef parts, however if you're looking for a flavorful bowl of pho noodles, DO NOT order this.

The soup was very unflavorful and bland. I used so much siracha just to have a little taste. ;(
author: Rose K.

description:
Great neighborhood Vietnamese restaurant to get your pho fix on!

My favorite dishes are the spring rolls and the bun/com thit nuong.

Service is great and I know I shouldn't advertise on someone else's page but another good thing about this place is that they're right next to PK!
author: Linda N.

description: Went to the Legion of Honor and was looking for somewhere for a late lunch nearby.  Also wanted something more ethnic than sandwiches or salads.  Checking out Yelp found Kim Son and really enjoyed it.  Food was fast in arriving, very good and lots of options.   We'll be back again when we need a lunch spot after going to the museum.
author: Karen S.

description:
FOOD:
1.) #16 Seafood Pho = Yum! clam, squid,  added meatballs. So perfect
2.) Rice Plates = I've had their rice plates here before and yep it's adequate for my San Jose hankerins of Vietnamese food. 



SERVICE:
Better than regular. Yay they give fortune cookie at the end! Unusual for Vietnamese restaurant, but they're appeasing to the dense Chinese population in SF


ATMOSPHERE:
Regular pho but with bigger round tables to accomodate large parties, perfect for our office team lunches
author: Angela L.

description: SUCH good pho. Perfect flavor, great timing, plenty of seating, and friendly wait staff. They even demo'd how to prepare the wraps we ordered, and then helped us try it ourselves. Really cool place that I'd be happy to go back to
author: Jessica G.

description: Man I love this place. I was blessed with living two blocks away. Their Pho is amazing! I eat it 2-3 times a week. I can't get enough. Their lunch special BBQ beef is also great. The family that own and run that place are very nice and respectful.
author: Kia Z.

description: The Bun Rieu is a revelation; it's just absolutely delicious. All of the other dishes here we've tried are solid to quite good, but I always get the Bun Rieu. The service is fast and friendly, and the vegetables served on the side are fresh and abundant. Generous portions all around, and inexpensive-- a super value.
author: Heather G.

description: Absolutely delicious lunch and good portion size. It's a plain no frills restaurant where the food is nominally priced. The menu is extensive and has vegetarian options as well. We ordered chicken pho/ soup which was seasoned just right and came in a super large bowl. We also ordered catfish in clay pot and vegetarian fried rice. They complimented each other like they were soulmates. I had no complaints with the service though the family that runs it is not the friendliest I've come across ,the food was good and there was plenty of parking outside the restaurant. All in all my family and I walked out happy and satisfied.
author: Kim M.

description:
I usually get pho tai, so I decided to order that. The food came out REALLY fast. There was no time for me to be "hangry" and I didn't complain. The broth was on the saltier side but it was overall good! I don't complain about too much meat but if you're a meat lover, you will definitely think that it's a bang for your buck!

I enjoyed my pho there, no complaints. I would come here for good pho!
author: Saewah K.

description:
Highly recommend.  Maybe I was just hungry after a long run at Golden Gate Park,  but the food here was very satisfying. 

We ordered a large bowl of pho and a bbq chicken plate that came with spring rolls. I recommend both dishes! The overwhelming number of reviews about the spring rolls are right, it's totally worth the try. 

The food here is great, and the service is excellent. I'd come back for another.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Good Stuff! Family run from what I can see. I have been here a couple times now and the service is the same very relaxed. Meaning you could be waiting a bit for water refills etc. as the service comes in waves and they have a small staff. Soup is great nothing crazy fancy, good flavor and hits the spot. 
Also located super close for me.
author: D R.

description: We enjoyed our first meal (lunch) on this San Francisco trip at this neighborhood restaurant. We had two types of pho and I had a bun bowl that included fried spring rolls. Huge portions were brought out quickly. Price was very reasonable. We were hard pressed to eat dinner late that night, still full of our flavorful lunch.
author: Chris R.

description: Good food over all, but I did not like the Vegetarian Imperial roll, didn't eat it, and they would not take it back. They made me pay for something I truly didn't enjoy after the first bite.
author: Lindsey H.

description:
Rice dishes are served with brown rice, not as an option but as the standard...WHAT?? Does this explain the clientele that dines here?? 

Special here is their Broken Rice:
Cm tm, or broken rice, is a Vietnamese dish made from rice with fractured rice grains. It is usually served with grilled pork (either ribs or shredded) plus the Vietnamese dish bì (thinly shredded pork mixed with cooked and thinly shredded pork skin) over broken rice. The rice and meat are served with various greens and pickled vegetables, along with a prawn paste cake, trng hp (steamed egg), and grilled prawns. Typically, restaurants will serve this popular combination rice plate with a small bowl of nc chm, as well as a small bowl of soup broth (canh) with garlic chives (to cleanse the throat). The dish cm tm bì comes with a ch trng egg meatloaf. The main ingredient, broken rice, is a traditionally cheaper grade of rice produced by damage in milling. Broken rice has a lower fiber and nutrient content, but generally has a similar energy content to intact rice.

Dishes are more expensive that what I'm used to paying for Vietnamese and I found my pork chops to be a bit tough. I've definitely had more flavorful and tender pork elsewhere. First time to try crispy Vietnamese noodles -- definitely different from HK pan fried noodles (same concept though). Don't think I'd come back. Sorry yelpers.
author: Cathrin P C.

description:
It was a cold, foggy Sunday night, and I was totally craving pho.  Kim Son is pretty outer Richmond and was kind of a trek, but I was drawn by the yelp photos of Bun rieu.

We started with imperial rolls, which have the more bumpy crunchy fried outside.  These were freshly fried, super juicy, well seasoned, and of course amazing with fish sauce.  Warning - they are VERY hot.

I got the bun rieu, which is supposed to be a crab paste tomato noodle soup.  It was more tomato dominant.  I think the traditional way should be more of a crab-egg-pork ball, but there wasn't as much crab in this one as I had hoped.  I think I actually preferred the noodles more in the #1 (traditional beef pho).  The pho was a HUGE bowl - like the kind for an eating challenge.  The broth was well seasoned without being too oily.  I also liked that the garnish included not only bean sprouts but also thinly sliced cabbage.

They were very nice about refilling water.  Food comes out quickly.  Bathrooms are clean, and they take cash or visa.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Solid Vietnamese place. I'd say it's a 3.5 but my friend's raving about their pho being so wonderfully flavored pushed it up.

Good portions, no wait, fast service. I got the BBQ pork over noodles. It seems a little pricier compared to other Vietnamese places, but then again I'm used to Westminster joints.

Oh, and bonus for being next to Purple Kow :)
author: Ruth H.

description:
After Pho Garden had shut down my life fell into a downward spiral... Where was I going to find my source of vegan pho?! Most Vietnamese restaurants don't have veggie broth so it seemed as if my life were over with..but then I found Kim Son, not only is there Veggie Pho just as good (if not better) it is in walking distance to my house! 
I would eat here everyday if I could, the only complaint I have is the atmosphere gets very loud very quick and gets me a little anxious. No biggie though.
author: Ashlyn G.

description: Wanting some Vietnamese coffee and a little snack I proceed into Pho Kim Son. As I enter I tell the woman who asks me "can I help you?" That I would like to order to go. She then points to the back of the restaurant. As I stand there waiting for the next person to help me, an elderly woman carrying a tray walks by. I ask her if I can place my order to go. She does not look back, she does not flinch, she does not acknowledge my being there. RUDE! A few moments later after being embarrassed, she comes back to me and says "what you want huh?" I say I would like a Vietnamese coffee and spring rolls to go. She said the coffee would take some time. Fine. I'll wait. 10 minutes pass and she hands me a cup FULL OF ICE AND CONDENSED MILK AND A LITTLE DROP OF COFFEE. I kid you not the cup was half way filled. I laugh. Wtf I paid $5 for this crap? I WILL NEVER COME BACK HERE AGAIN. SERVICE=RUDE AF! They will hustle money out of you! Go somewhere else!
author: Marie N.

description:
Love this place during my high school days! The family here are very nice and welcoming. Their like your typical vietnamese family that make you feel like their your family. This is coming from a vietnamese guy that is use to the vietnamese family feeling. 

The food is delicious and the service is always consistent.
author: Kelly N.

description:
Really good food. Very generous portions. Usually when you order com tam suon (pork chops with broken rice), other places only give you one pork chop, but Kim Son will give you TWO! My pork chops were perfectly seasoned and juicy. Imperial rolls were also delicious. 

I also ordered bun rieu to go on a different occasion and they packed my broth with crab/egg! My bun rieu broth wasn't as "salty" as how I usually like it but it was still flavorful and delicious. I think they might have toned down on the fermented shrimp past in the broth, which is my favorite part, but I understand it might be too stinky for other people. 

Fast service.
author: LeTran B.

description:
Pros:
1.  Best Vietnamese food I've found in SF so far at a reasonable price.
2.  Parking is not usually that bad.
3.  Try the BBQ Pork Spring Rolls ( very good)
4.  Clean and Friendly

Cons:
1.  Closed on Thursdays
2.  Closed by 9pm
author: Jensen L.

description:
One of my favorite places to get pho in SF. Not the best pho I've ever had but I think in general SF doesnt have many good options. That being said I usually come here for their pho. Their other dishes are worth trying too! 
The staff here are really great. Im always happy eating at this restaurant because of that. Im assuming the older gentleman is the owner- he seems like a very humble and attentive person. Whenever I've looked around to pay the check or ask a question he always notices.
Im giving this restaurant a 5 star review because I really haven't found a better pho place. Turtle Tower is good but its a different style of pho.
author: S S.

description:
We invaded Balboa Street again since there was no parking on Clement Street. Kim Son offers the usual Vietnamese dishes, Pho, and other delights. For 30.00 we got the fresh spring rolls which were tasty, I ordered some dish ( # 41) where chicken,seafood and vegetables covered this birds nest of dry noodles, smothered in a tasty brown sauce, making them soft. It was really good. The Misses had the pork with shredded pork, fish cake with rice. It was all good and tasty but the portions were EPIC. Make sure you are hungry as in not eaten in like 6 - 8 hours. I could not believe the size of the portions here. My plate was HUGE and was completely covered in food. I was looking at some people eating Pho Noodle soup and the bowl was so deep and humongous,  that looked like you could hide your head inside of it. This is not for the petite eater in you, this was another hungry man's place. I liked my wife's dish better than mine but everything was just yummy. I do prefer larger portions as I hate spending 10.00+ on a meal and theres plenty of room on the plate still. 
Come hungry, leave happy :)
author: David S.

description: My girlfriend and I tried this spot tonight. It was my first time trying bun reiu. Loved it! Delicious and very hearty serving. She ordered the 5 spice chicken, and we split an order of the imperial rolls which were both very delicious. Will definitely come back again!
author: Erick S.

description:
Here on Saturday noon and service is very fast.

They have some of my fave vegetarian dishes:

Vegetarian pho

Veggie crispy noodles (be sure to clarify no seafood unless you enjoy it)

Excellent value.
author: George K.

description:
What attracts me here: Hu Tieu but at a hefty price at close to $9. What sets this bowl apart from the other restaurants is that they use the southern type of pho noodles with the fried shrimp cake. I love the lightness and flavor of the broth. Its usually busy here despite the many reviews complaining its mediocre. My bf isnt a fan either, but then again, he has the luxury of eating home cooked pho, of course its mediocre to him! 

parking: metered spaces can be tough, but if you don't mind parking on cabrillo, there's usually plenty of space. 

other nearby gems: cassava for cookies, purple kow for boba drinks, Marla for baked goods
author: Connie C.

description: Located in the Richmond area of San Francisco.  We were a party of 3.  All of us ordered different varieties of pho, fresh rolls, and imperial rolls.  Everything was pretty good.  Spring rolls tasted like all other Vietnamese restaurants, but the imperial rolls stood out.  We even ordered an extra set to-go and we live 2 hours away.  My taste test is the pho broth.  I taste it before adding anything.  It passed the test - no need to add anything to it, but I did anyways.  Decent spot for pho.  Bathroom setup was a bit weird with the sink outside the toilet.  Parking was fairly easy to find - mostly parking meters.
author: Will C.

description: My all time favorite Vietnamese restaurant, the flavors rest in your mouth just right. Not to mention they didn't mind at all that my dogs were parked out front of the restaurant, barking the entire time. The servers were so very nice and got us everything we needed. Not to mention the owner came out and said hello and told us what we had to try. Although my mom is one tough cookie, she was fairly impressed with this place and even ended up fighting with me over what food she wanted to take home. Most definitely a hidden gem, parking is fairly easy, and right down the street is a super cute café for some espresso afterwards. A must go to spot if you're in the area, plus if you're not sure what kind of Vietnamese food you would like then go ahead and ask the waiter to recommend their most popular dishes. They have a ton of options to choose from! Can't wait to go back!
author: Mary E.

description:
Yay! I'm a fan! 

I just dropped by for a late dinner today. I walked in at 8:50PM when they posted that they close at 9:00PM. I was glad that they didn't kick me out because I would've gone hulk from being hangry!

I ordered the broken rice dish with egg cake, shredded pork skin, and grilled pork. I thought it was definitely a solid dish. I liked my egg cake. It wasn't too salty like some places. My grilled pork was also perfectly marinated and not overpowered by lemongrass. 

Service was also terrific. The man who took our order brought our check over at around 9:30PM. He made sure to tell us not to hurry and to take our time eating. Honestly, I've never been to such a pleasant Chinese/Vietnamese establishment. I mean, lets be honest with ourselves. Half the time when we walk into restaurants like these, we kind of expect crappy service. But not here! 

Overall, had a very positive experience here. It's also located right next to Purple Kow. Bubble tea dessert anyone!?
author: Thy L.

description: I came on a Sunday afternoon and the place was packed, line out the door! I've never seen this place this packed before. I looked on yelp and looked like the more popular dish was the crab tomato noodle soup so that's what I got! You yelpers didn't fail me this time! I think it was the best I've had in SF. It had a bunch of shrimp huge pieces of pork and crab. My favorite part was the yummy fried tofu with a soft center. Huge bowl filled me up, finished my bowl but my friend barely put a dent in hers (light eaters can share it). We also shared a fried spring roll appetizer it was descent, good flavors solid. This place might be my goto spot for this noodle soup now. I also got a iced Vietnamese coffee, can't go wrong with that.
author: Karen T.

description: Damn, that was good. Price was $24 for two, so that's why I give them 4 stars otherwise, food was BOMB
author: Tan D.

description: To start, I'm going to tell you not about the food but about the service. Spoiler: it is hot and cold. On one occasion late on a rainy night I called for take out. When I arrived to pick it up, I discovered they gave my order to the wrong white dude. They apologized and offered me free tea while I waited for them to remake my food: point plus. On another occasion my wife and I went in for lunch. It was a slow day and most of the restaurant was empty. We were directed to a small table in the back. We asked if we could sit at a larger "table for four", and the woman (the owner?) said flatly "no" for no reason. The place was empty and she was going to force us to sit at a tiny table. We left: point lost. So now that you know my history, I've still gone many times since. The food quality is high; their pho is delicious with a hearty broth base. I also appreciate having a selection of other dishes. I just don't always appreciate the attitude, like when I was clearly judged for not ordering a beverage. Hot and cold.
author: Michael B.

description:
Hands down the best bun I've had in San Francisco. Tasty pho, with a fine broth. No-frills decor but most excellent taste. 

Cheap white wine, too, so there you go!
author: Andy D.

description:
Best vegetarian pho in San Francisco! I've been all over the city looking for a place that uses vegetable broth in their pho and this is one of the only places that does. They also put a ton of different vegetables and tofu that actually result in you being full. The broth is the super flavorful too. My boyfriend usually gets #1: the house special, which is giant and he usually finishes all of it. 
We go here like twice a month, and just recently got deep fried vegetable rolls which were surprisingly tasty and full of deep fried tofu! We also got deep fried bananas which we took home and put some three twins ice cream on top of.
author: Emma G.

description: First time I came here it was an acceptable experience, iffy service but really good pho. I recently came back and it was awful service. We waited 40 minutes for someone to acknowledge us after receiving our food, I had to yell politely for the man to receive another beer and he turned around like it was as an inconvenience. With a little friendly service this place would be much better.
author: Casey C.

description:
If your looking for a good bowl of Bun Bo Hue (Traditional Spicy Beef Noodle Soup), please look elsewhere..

Bun Bo Hue - http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=pP7HnhQn07UefqVzripI7Q&userid=5jUlCtMCI9Z7poi1vHq6cQ
It was pretty disappointing. Rather than various pig limbs and coagulated blood, it was just slices of typical beef flank and a sponge of fish cake. The broth itself was spicy, but it honestly tasted like they just bathed a regular bowl of pho with some spicy msg (see photo). Long review-short, I've definitely had better, a lot better. 

Why 1-star?
We came here the other day with a couple of friends, my girlfriend, and myself. I ordered the (subpar) Bun Bo Hue and my girlfriend ordered just a regular pho but she wanted her slices of beef on the side, so a side of raw beef she got. The next day, I felt very ill with a high fever and the constant "dash" to the yknowwhat. On the other hand, my girlfriend was a little more fortunate and felt a-okay, after vomiting in the morning.. I've asked my buddies if they caught anything after eating at Kim Son's but they were all fine.

the culprit? the side of raw beef my girlfriend and I shared..
author: Albert L.

description:
I've had a plentiful amount of fresh spring rolls in my day.... but there are very few that are actually literally FRESH, like the ones from Kim Son Vietnamese Restaurant. The basil and mint are so refreshing, I could literally eat a whole order (4 tiny tiny tiny, [JK not that tiny, im just saying that so I wont feel like a fatty mcfat fat]) pieces to myself! The shrimp and pork inside the spring rolls are again, fresh. In some spring rolls the shrimp and pork taste kind of old or gamey, but not in these. No sir. Their peanut dipping sauce is amazing as well.  My cousin and I also ordered the bun rieu, which she SWEARS BY, and will literally eat once a week. I had a little bit of this, and because of the red broth, I wanted it to be spicy, but was a little disappointed when it wasn't! Other than that, it was really good. The tofu is nice and chewy and the whole bowl is food for your soul. I personally ordered the vermicilli noodle bowl with bbq pork and regular spring rolls. BBQ pork was nice and flavorfu! Service is good, it's a run by a mom&pops, so they go a little slow. Food came out pretty quickly, but they kinda just let us sit with our empty bowls and plates for a minute, maybe because we were story telling like crazy, so that's why one star has been knocked off. 

Did I mention the spring rolls are fresh?
author: Kathleene E.

description: Ehhh. Good pho is few and far between in the city. This place is no exception to the statistic in SF of sub standard pho. It's simple, straight forward, not a great deal, not expensive either. Just very average overall. Staff is chill
author: Elton F.

description:
On the Balboa strip there are two pho options... this is the greater choice because can you really justify ordering pho from a place that also serves breakfast and faux-talian cuisine? But it is not just the lesser of two evils... I love Kim Son! And the people are nice and friendly! I usually always order in, but even when I've picked up it tastes good and travels well. (And ya i know, cardinal rule with pho is you never order out!)

Anywhere else I usually always get Pho Ga because I never feel like the beef parts are very fresh or they taste odd. But here?! Sign me up for a large #1 with all them beefy goodness!! Most times the tendons are extremely tender and perfectly gelatinous. The tripe has a good bite, but not like chewing on rope. The broth is awesome, smooth, salty, sweet. I don't usually kill my soup with sriracha because I like to taste the broth, i just add all the herbs.

Another favorite is for the 75% of the time when I crave vegetarian... Their veggie pho is jam packed with greens, mushrooms, broccoli, fried tofu. And their veggie broth is flavorful! Not a watered down, thin soup that one might expect. I love how much more full this veggie soup makes me over the pho!

And lastly I will end with the bowl that lured me in and will keep me forever.. the bowl that I've tried to order at other places and extreme regret followed that I was not here.... BUN RIEU. It's crazy amazing. Just order it. Go.
author: Rachelle F.

description: I followed recommendations for #24, tomato with shrimp.  With extra lime, all of the Holy Basil and sprouts, it did not need any added sauces.  The broth has great, full flavor.  Outside of a little Sunday afternoon pop up place straight from Eden, this is the best Pho I've had in the Bay area.
author: Ilsa S.

description:
Had to get a second lunch down on Saturday (long story) and was stuck in the Outer Richmond. Ate a Bun Rieu and an Iced Viet Coffee.

The Bun Rieu had a rich broth with the right amount of sodium. They put in fried tofu squares and shrimp. It warmed my soul very nicely. The iced Viet coffee was nice and strong. Almost ordered the fried shrimp rolls, but that will be something to look forward to for next time.

The owners are super-friendly, plus the restaurant is good-sized and very clean.

I ate my second lunch at about 3:00pm and the place was full. 
Sounds like a lot of dedicated Kim Son foodies! 
Or, perhaps they were getting their 2nd lunch on!
author: Derek N.

description:
I was going to give Kim Son Vietnamese a better rating, but a few hours after having lunch there I did not feel good.

The location is cool, literally, within sight of the Pacific Ocean located in area of Asian restaurants called the "Richmond District."

The place was filled with Asian people, always a good sign.

My lunch was chicken with lemon grass and chili sauce. I am too sensitive to be eating such food. I should have had something else.

My buddy ate the lunch special of BBQ chicken, rice, soup for $9.99. I ate the chicken it was nice. The price could be less.

The service was good and I would go back.
author: Mr. O.

description:
I'm a big Vietnamese fan and this place nails the cuisine. The vermicelli bowl was one of the best I've ever had. 

My girl got a chicken salad and it was humongous. All of the sweet carrots, lettuce and mint were very vibrant.  

The service is great. Very very attentive. 

I would definitely return.
author: Dusty B.

description: The bun Riu was all that other reviewers said. The bowl is huge too, so enough for take home.  I asked for extra lime and the soup was fantastic without any additional sauces. Prompt service. I'll definitely be back.
author: elsa z.

description:
One of the best Pho places I have been to.  Great value.  Huge bowl of beef Pho for $7.  I went here one afternoon for lunch and I got seated right away.  After I ordered it didn't take that long to receive my Pho.  It was great service and great food at a great price.  I will definitely be returning.

P.S.  They accept credit cards, but you have to have a minimum order of $10.
author: Rose Z.

description: I know my Phō. I'm kind of an addict. Throw in some imperial rolls and I lose my mind. Pho Kim Son makes me lose my mind and then soothes my soul. My go to for sure.
author: Heysoos R.

description:
Combination beef pho was one of the best in town. All three parts were equally excelent and balanced: broth was complex but clean and delicious, noodles had the perfect toothiness, and all the fixings were just right: beef balls, fatty beef, thin beef (though not as raw as you sometimes get), tripe and tendon. The tendon was the standout. At $9 the small size was a little on the expensive side but very generous, it more than filled me up.

Atmosphere was pleasant enough, service was prompt and orderly. Another dish, the Hong Kong seafood noodles, was kind of average but they get a pass on that, don't order Chinese food in a Vietnamese restaurant okay?

This is going to be a new standard for me and pho.
author: Gil S.

description: Get the bbq pork or 5 spiced chicken in any or the forms but my favorite has got to be the vermicelli noodle salad with bbq pork and imperial rolls BOMB!!!  Been eating here for 10 years and always a great meal.  If you want grab the 5 spice chicken and get the bbq pork spring rolls.  Or you can get the bbq pork pho its really all about the bbq pork!
author: C M.

description: I usually can't take my eyes off my boyfriend when he's sitting across from me.. Until I met the chicken curry noodle soup! So flavorful, creamy, tender chicken and affordable! I think I even had a dream I was still eating it, it's THAT good!
author: Kristine P.

description:
Been here a few times because its in my neighborhood.  Don't like the pho broth, ordered it the first time and never again.  It just doesn't have the beefy flavor like the real deal Vietnamese in San Jose.  Their rice plates are similar, you have to order the combo or ask for the Vietnamese rice or it will be regular steamed Jasmine.  I come here for there salt and pepper prawns and Hoi Nam chicken.  The prawns are the ones that they fry very well and you can eat the whole thing including head and shells.  The chicken is flavorful with lots of chinese green onions.  I have this with the regular steamed rice.  

Good, friendly service.
author: Kevin L.

description: Omg, so delicious.. Smaller portion and kinda pricey compared to most pho places, but good flavor!
author: Droolie Y.

description: Delicious! I love the food this restaurant offers. It taste fresh and they bring the food out quickly. The missing start is for the service. The Wait-stuff could care more about offering dessert or else before bringing the check immediately, that is kind of rude. I guess that can be easy fix, but again, food is super good.
author: Coté M.

description:
We happened upon Kim Son Pho on accident. Our intention was to go to Purple Kow to grab some drinks and snacks but we were in the mood for something soupy. It was a little chilly that morning so we wanted something warm.

We were driving by, trying to scope out a parking spot, when we saw Kim Son Pho. Looked it up on Yelp and there was a fair amount of positive reviews (~250), with an overall rating of 4 stars. So what the heck, we decided to sit down and try them out. There was a good amount of people sitting down (surprising because it was a Friday around 1PM) and no students around (because they normally swarm the area around lunch time and when they're let out of school).

The place is pretty cleanly and tables are pretty well spaced apart; enough that you don't feel like you're eavesdropping on the next table. I ordered the #1 (large, regular pho bowl with thinly slices beef, beef balls, tendons, and veg. The soup was pretty good, not too sweet nor sour, but well balanced. My two knocks for the meal would the largeness of the bowl and the smidgen higher price ($8.95 + tax). Bowl was too large for the amount of food in the bowl. The price wasn't something that would break the camels back for me. Overall, would definitely recommend this place and I'd come back again to eat here.
author: Lenerd J.

description: Went around dinner time on a weekend. Pretty busy, but only had to wait maybe 5 mins. Had to see what all the fuss was about. The Bun Rieu was delicious! It did remind me of something I've had before, but this was the first time trying it. First time having Bun Rieu ever, actually. Omg, I was so full, but I couldn't stop eating it. That's how good it was. Yum. So filling and tasty! Service was ok. They were busy and they didn't have too many people working, but when they did interact with us they were nice. I would definitely come back. I'm inspired to try Bun Rieu at other spots to compare now! haha.
author: Mariel A.

description: I have been here as a kid but the owner has changed. This was my first time back after that and ordered the bun bo hue. It wasn't flavorful enough but the spice was good enough. We also had the beef carpaccio which was delicious. It did cost $12 but they give a fairly large portion. Will be back to have pho since I think that's the better and more popular choice.
author: Amanda C.

description: Favorite spot for Pho.  Good broth, nice space, good people.  Prices are fair, and potions are good.
author: Darin D.

description: If you like Beef, the #1 Pho on the menu is dynamite. The Large bowl is huuuuge. Plenty of leftovers
author: Owen N.

description:
So, I got a touch of the sick during my stay in SF, and considering how shite you tend to feel when you get sick, I needed some soup. However, I'm in SF. A tin of Campbell's was not going to do the job.

Cut to Kim Son.

Right in the easiest walking distance from where I'm staying, and full of pho.

Yes, this would be the place.

Got in, was shown to a table. Ordered the chicken pho.

I like that they indicate on the menu that it's made with free range chicken. The pho came out quickly, and it was just what the doctor ordered. 

Flavorful - and I could tell even with my stuffed up nose! 
Hot. 
Lots of chicken and noodles. 
Nice price!

I added all the goodies and enough sriracha to make my nose run some more.

So filling and hot and soothing. It made me feel loads better, and the staff didn't bother me too much, pretty much being able to suss out when I wanted to order and when I was finished and wanted the check.

Nice little place. Clearly very well-liked restaurant by the neighborhood.
author: Cate T.

description: Was hungry after waiting so long for my drink at PurpleKow so I decided to come here for lunch. I got there #1 combo where I would usually get when I eat pho. The bowl of pho was a bit smaller than expected and the soup was lacking flavor so I had to drench it with hot sauce. The service here was also lacking where our water and tea were never refilled during the duration of our meal. The prices here were also a bit high for Vietnamese food.
author: Peter C.

description:
The food here is solid. 

Good flavors, good service, fairly inexpensive. The owner is always making rounds and is very nice. They also make it a point to make sure you are done with your meal before leaving the check at your table. It's the small considerations that make a big impact in the end. 

The BBQ chicken is surprisingly good here! (tender, dark meat, flavorful skin, slightly on the sweeter side, but not by much. I don't like sweet meats and it was tolerable). The BBQ pork is good too. I ordered an egg cake, though tasty, I've had better ones elsewhere. 

The pho is flavorful, and I really enjoyed the curry chicken soup! Squeeze a lime into it and it tastes completely different! In a good way!
